(f)  Issue such publications and such results of investigations and research as in its judgment will tend to minimize or eliminate discrimination because of race, color, religion, sex, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation or gender identity, or familial status in the case of housing. 
(g)  Prepare and issue a report annually to the Common Council and Mayor, describing in detail the investigation and conciliation proceedings it has conducted and their outcome, the progress made and any other work performed and achievements towards the elimination of discrimination. 
(h)  Prevent any person from discharging, expelling or otherwise discriminating against any other person because he filed a charge or has testified in any hearing before this Commission, or has in any way assisted the Commission in any matter under investigation. 
(i)  Appoint hearing officers, hold hearings, subpoena witnesses, compel their attendance, administer oaths, take the testimony of any such person under oath, and require the production for examination of any books and papers relating to any matter under investigation or in question before the Commission. The Commission shall have the exclusive power to subpoena, but it shall consult with the Department of Law concerning the issuance of a subpoena. The Department of Law may veto the issuance of a subpoena if and only if such an issuance would be an abuse of the Commission's subpoena power. Abuse of the Commission's subpoena power shall include but not be limited to use of such subpoena power for harassment purposes, issuance of a subpoena for information clearly irrelevant to the investigation being conducted, and issuance of a subpoena for information over an excessively broad span of time. Contumacy or refusal to obey a subpoena issued pursuant to this section shall constitute a contempt. All hearings shall be held within the City of South Bend at a location determined by the Commission. A citation of contempt may be issued upon application by the Commission to the circuit or superior court, or judge thereof, in the County in which the hearing is held or in which the witness resides or transacts business. 
(1)  The Commission shall state its finding of fact after a hearing, and, if the Commission finds a person has engaged in an unlawful discriminatory practice, it may cause to be served on such person an order requiring such person to cease and desist from the unlawful discriminatory practice and requiring such person to take further affirmative action as will effectuate the purposes of this article, including but not limited to the power to restore charging party's losses incurred as a result of discriminatory treatment, as the Commission may deem necessary to assure justice. The Commission may require the posting of notice setting forth the public policy of Indiana concerning civil rights and the respondent's compliance with said policy in places of public accommodations; and it may require proof of compliance to be filed by the respondent at periodic intervals. 
(A)  Except in housing cases which are separately treated in sub-part (C) of this section, the Commission may impose a penalty upon any respondent of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for the first and second violation of this article within a five-year period, and may further impose a penalty of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for three (3) or more violations of this article within a five-year period. 
(B)  When applied to discrimination in employment, the Commission shall also have power, to the extent consistent with state law , to restore charging party's losses by awarding damages including wages, salary, commissions, fringe benefits in an amount not to exceed that lost over a two-year period. For discrimination in employment and housing, the Commission shall also have the power, to the extent consistent with state law, to award damages which will compensate charging party for future pecuniary loss, emotional pain, suffering, inconvenience, anguish, loss of enjoyment of life and other non-pecuniary losses, costs and attorney fees. 
(C)  To vindicate the public interest in cases of housing discrimination, the Commission may assess a civil penalty of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for each commission of a discriminatory housing practice. 
(D)  The Commission may sue to recover a civil penalty due under this section. [P.L. 66-1990, § 2.] 
(2)  Judicial review of any decision of the Commission as referred to in this article may be obtained under IC 4-21.5-1 in the same manner as if the decision was that of a State agency. However, only in those cases involving discriminatory housing practices as prohibited by this Chapter, a complainant, a respondent, or an aggrieved person on whose behalf the complaint was filed may elect to have decided in a civil action those claims asserted in a finding of probable cause. Such election must be made not later than twenty (20) days after the date of receipt by the electing person of service under this chapter, and such person shall give written notice to the Commission and all other complainants and respondents to whom the finding of probable cause relates. Such civil action shall be filed in the circuit or superior court of St. Joseph County or any other court of proper jurisdiction, and if the court finds that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, the court may grant any relief appropriate in a civil action under this Article or IC 22-9.5-8.1-2 or as authorized by the Civil Rights Act of 1991, or the federal Fair Housing Act. 
(3)  In those cases involving discriminatory housing practices as prohibited by this Act where final adjudicative Commission action is in favor of the charging party, the charging party shall be permitted to have damages determined in the circuit of superior court of St. Joseph County or any other court of proper jurisdiction having the power to award punitive damages as allowed by the Fair Housing Act. Charging parties shall make such a request to the Commission in writing within five (5) days from the notice of final Commission action, which notice shall advise charging party of this right to damage determination, and the Commission shall represent charging party at the Commission's expense in such court action for damages. The Commission shall seek such a judicial determination of damages within one (1) year of the alleged discriminatory housing practice. If it is impracticable for the Commission to seek such a determination within one (1) year of the alleged discriminatory act, it shall notify charging party and respondent in writing of its reasons for not doing so, and shall undertake such judicial determination as soon as practicable. 
(j)  Reduce the terms of conciliation agreed to by the parties to a writing to be called a "consent agreement" which the parties and a majority of the Commissioners shall sign and when so signed the consent agreement shall have the same effect as a final decision of the Commission. If the Commission determines that a party to a consent agreement is not complying with the agreement, the Commission may obtain enforcement of the consent agreement in a circuit or superior court upon showing that the party is subject to the Commission's jurisdiction. 
(k)  Institute actions in the St. Joseph Superior or Circuit Court for appropriate or equitable relief. 
(l)  Transfer cases to the Indiana Civil Rights Commission or to an appropriate federal agency and to receive cases transferred from the Indiana Civil Rights Commission or from an appropriate federal agency. The South Bend Human Rights Commission shall proceed to act on any case transferred to it from the Indiana Civil Rights Commission as if the case had been originally filed with the South Bend Human Rights Commission as of the date the charge was filed with the Indiana Civil Rights Commission. 
(Ord. No. 5619-73, § 1; Ord. No. 6003-76; Ord. No. 6635-79, § 1; Ord. No. 8277-92, § 8, 7-13-92; Ord. No. 8410-93, § 1; Ord. No. 8699-96, § I, 7-22-96; Ord. No. 10154-12, § VII, 3-26-12) 
Sec. 2-132. - Discrimination in performance of City contracts. 
    Every contract to which the City is a party, including franchises granted to the public utilities, shall contain a provision requiring the contractor and his subcontractor not to discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment who is to be employed in the performance of such contracts with respect to his hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment, because of his race, religion, color, sex, handicap, national origin or ancestry. Breach of this covenant may be considered a material breach of the contract. 
(Ord. No. 5619-73, § 1; Ord. No. 6003-76; Ord. No. 6635-79, § 1) 
Sec. 2-132.1. - Private enforcement.[31] 
    This section may be enforced by an aggrieved charging party through the commencement of an action in the St. Joseph County circuit or superior court or any other court of proper jurisdiction not less than one (1) year after the occurrence or termination of the alleged discriminatory practice. 
(Ord. No. 8410-93, § 1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (31) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8410-93, § 1, added a new § 2-133. In order to avoid duplicative section numbering, such provisions have been redesignated as § 2-132.1 at the discretion of the editor. 

ARTICLE 10. - CIVIL DEFENSE AGENCY MERIT PLAN[32] 

Footnotes: 
--- (32) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency Management and Disaster Law IC 10-14-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-133. - Establishment of merit system.[33] 
    There is established a merit system of personnel administration for employees of the Civil Defense Agency of the City, to be serviced by the State Personnel Division. 
(Code 1962, § 2-28) 
Footnotes: 
--- (33) --- 
State Law reference- State Personnel Act, IC 4-15-2-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-134. - Persons exempt from system. 
(a)  The Civil Defense Director shall be exempt from the merit system of the personnel administration for the employees of the Civil Defense Agency. 
(b)  Any individuals who are not prescribed by the State Personnel Division as being included in the merit system shall be exempt from same. 
(Code 1962, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-135. - Designation of County Civil Defense Advisory Council. 
    For the purposes of administering the merit program for employees of the Civil Defense Agency, the County Civil Defense Advisory Council is considered and designated as the appointing council. 
(Code 1962, § 2-30) 
Sec. 2-136. - Agreements authorized with the State Personnel Division. 
(a)  The County Civil Defense Advisory Council is authorized and directed to enter into such arrangements and agreements with the State Department of Civil Defense and the State Personnel Division as may be necessary to provide for a continuing merit program of personnel administration for City civil defense employees. 
(b)  Such merit program shall be serviced by the State Personnel Division, pursuant to the authority granted by IC 4-15-2-36 of the State Personnel Act. It shall meet Federal merit system standards of the United States Department of Defense, including the exemption of any positions from the merit program as is recognized in these same Federal standards. 
(Code 1962, § 2-31)

ARTICLE 12. - PUBLIC CEMETERIES[35] 

Footnotes: 
--- (35) --- 
Editor's note- Section 7 of Ord. No. 7108-82, repealed former Art. 12 and enacted, in lieu thereof, a new Art. 12, as herein set out, pertaining to the same subject matter. Former Art. 12 consisted of §§ 2-138-2-150 which derived from §§ 10-4-10-11 of the 1962 Code. 

Sec. 2-138. - Board of Public Works administration. 
    The Board of Public Works shall have the control and management of all public cemeteries owned by the City and located within five (5) miles of the City. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 7) 
Sec. 2-139. - Perpetual Care Fund. 
(a)  A Perpetual Care Fund is established as a trust fund under the control and direction of the Board of Public Works for the purpose of providing for the perpetual care and maintenance of the City cemetery. 
(b)  The Board shall not be obligated to expend for care on any lot in excess of the interest earned and received from legal investment made by the Board. 
(c)  The Board shall not assume liability for the maintenance of the whole or any part of the principal of the amount received as Perpetual Care Funds. 
(d)  Funds received for the Perpetual Care Fund of any lot shall be kept separately and not commingled with any other funds. 
(e)  The Board shall not accept less than two dollars ($2.00) per square foot as funds for the perpetual care of any lot in a City cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 7) 
Sec. 2-140. - Extension of cemetery ground. 
(a)  No person shall enlarge or extend any burial ground in a City cemetery except in compliance with this section. 
(b)  Any person wishing to enlarge or extend any burial ground in a City cemetery shall file with the Board of Public Works a petition setting forth his request and including an accurate description of the land constituting such enlargement or extension. 
(c)  The Board shall indicate its approval of such a petition by written resolution embodying the specific description of ground to be enlarged or extended. 
(d)  No body may be buried in any extension or enlargement of burial ground in a City cemetery prior to the approval by the Board of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 7) 
Sec. 2-141. - Rules of conduct for City cemeteries. 
(a)  The sexton may expel from the City cemetery anyone who violates the rules of conduct under this section. Such expulsion shall not preclude prosecution by the Law Department for ordinance violation. 
(b)  The following conduct is prohibited in City cemeteries: 
(1)  Driving a vehicle faster than fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(2)  Taking or removing any flower, tree or shrub. 
(3)  Defacing, disfiguring or injuring any monument, fence, or other structure within the cemetery. This subsection shall not prevent the alteration or removal of any structure or monument on a private lot or grave by persons so authorized. 
(4)  Discharge of firearms, except at military funerals and memorial celebrations. 
(5)  Sitting upon, walking or otherwise occupying any private lot unless so authorized. 
(6)  Use of the city cemetery for any purpose other than as a burying ground. 
(7)  Committing any nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 7) 
Secs. 2-142-2-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 13. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT TARGET AREAS[36] 

Footnotes: 
--- (36) --- 
Editor's note- Section 8 of Ord. No. 7108-82 repealed former Ch. 13, §§ 2-151-2-153, which pertained to the firemen's pension fund and derived from §§ 13-1-13-3 of the 1962 Code. Subsequently, Ord. No. 7267-83, adopted Nov. 14, 1983, enacted a new Art. 13, § 2-151, as herein set forth. 
Cross reference- Economic Development Department established, functions, § 2-13; Economic Development Commission, § 2-56. 

Sec. 2-151. - Areas designated. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-7-12-3, the following specific geographic territories of the City of South Bend shall be economic development target areas: 
(a)  The area commonly known as the South Bend Central Development Area, a parcel of land being a part of the City of South Bend, Portage Township, St. Joseph County, Indiana, and being more particularly described as follows, viz: 
    Beginning at the point of intersection of the south right-of-way line of Sample Street with the west right-of-way line of Michigan Street; thence north along said west right-of-way line of Michigan Street to its intersection with the northerly line of the Conrail Railroad (formerly Penn Central) right-of-way; thence northwesterly along said northerly railroad right-of-way line to its intersection with the southerly projection of the west right-of-way line of Taylor Street; thence north along said west right-of-way line to its intersection with the westerly projection of the north right-of-way line of Monroe Street; thence east along said projection and the north right-of-way line of said Monroe Street to its intersection with the southerly projection of the centerline of the first 14-foot alley lying west of Lafayette Boulevard; thence north along said projection and the centerline of said 14-foot alley to the south right-of-way line of Washington Street; thence west along said south right-of-way line to the east right-of-way line of William Street; thence north along said east right-of-way line to the north right-of-way line of Colfax Avenue; thence east along said north right-of-way line to the centerline of the first 14-foot alley lying west of Lafayette Boulevard; thence north along said centerline, in certain places being sometimes known as St. James Court, to the north right-of-way line of LaSalle Street; thence east along said north right-of-way line to the west right-of-way line of Michigan Street; thence north along said west right-of-way line to the westerly projection of the north line of Lot 111 in the Original Plat to the Town, now City of South Bend; thence east along said projection, the north line of said Lot 111 and its easterly projection to the centerline of the St. Joseph River; thence meandering northeasterly and northwesterly along said centerline to the westerly projection of the south right-of-way line of Corby Street; thence east along said projection and the south right-of-way line of said Corby Street to the centerline of the first 14-foot alley lying west of Hill Street; thence south along said centerline to the north right-of-way line of Crescent Avenue; thence southeasterly to the point of intersection of the south right-of-way line of said Crescent Avenue with the centerline of the first 14-foot alley lying west of said Hill Street; thence southeasterly, southwesterly and south along the centerline of said alley to the centerline of the first 14-foot alley lying north of Cedar Street; thence east along said centerline to the centerline of the first 14-foot alley lying east of Hill Street; thence south along said centerline to the south right-of-way line of Jefferson Boulevard; thence west along said south right-of-way line to the centerline of the St. Joseph River; thence southeasterly along said centerline to the easterly projection of the southerly right-of-way line of Monroe Street; thence southwesterly along said projection and the southerly right-of-way line of Monroe Street to the easterly right-of-way line of Lincolnway East (U.S. Highway No. 33); thence southeasterly along said easterly right-of-way line to the south right-of-way line of Sample Street; ARTICLE 14. - SPECIAL FUNDS[37] 

Footnotes: 
--- (37) --- 
Editor's note- Section 9 of Ord. No. 7108-82 repealed former Art. 14 and enacted, in lieu thereof a new Art. 14 as herein set forth. Former Art. 14, which consisted of §§ 2-154-2-158 pertaining to sinking funds, derived from §§ 13-4-13-8 of the 1962 Code. 

Sec. 2-154. - Bond sinking fund created. 
    A bond sinking fund is created for the gradual extinguishment of the bonded indebtedness of the City. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-155. - City development fund. 
(a)  A City development fund is created to be used to pay expenses incurred in promoting the betterment of the City including, but not necessarily limited to, the following: 
(1)  Membership dues in local, regional, state and national associations of a civic, educational or governmental nature which have as their purpose the betterment and improvement of municipal operations. 
(2)  Direct expenses for travel, meals and lodging in conjunction with City business or meetings of organizations to which the City belongs. 
(3)  Expenses incurred in the promotion of economic or industrial development for the City including, but not limited to, meeting room rental, meals, decorations, travel, awards, memorabilia. 
(4)  Expenses incurred in interviewing job applicants. 
(5)  Expenses incurred in developing relations with other units of government. 
(6)  Other expenses of a civic or governmental nature deemed to be in the best interest of the City. 
(b)  Each year the City budget shall include separate sub-accounts within the City development fund for the Mayor, the Common Council, the Economic Development Department and other City entities or departments, as deemed appropriate by the Common Council, appropriating the amounts to be expended under each sub-account pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Each year the City budget may also include monies for promotional activities for the Office of the Mayor, the Common Council, the Economic Development Department and other City entities as deemed appropriate by the Common Council. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9; Ord. No. 7768, § 1) 
Sec. 2-156. - Cumulative capital improvement fund. 
    A cumulative capital improvement fund is continued for purposes permitted under IC 36-9-16. It shall be funded and operated in accordance with statutory requirements. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-157. - Cumulative street fund. 
    A cumulative street fund is created to provide money for the acquisition of rights-of-way for public ways and sidewalks and the construction and reconstruction of public ways and sidewalks. It shall be funded and operated in accordance with IC 36-9-16.5. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-158. - Cumulative sewer building and sinking fund. 
    A cumulative sewer building and sinking fund is continued for purposes permitted under IC 36-9-26. It shall be funded and operated in accordance with statutory requirements. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2.158.1. - Sewage works bond debt reserve fund. 
    A sewage works bond debt reserve fund (#653) is created as the repository for the City's Sewage Works Bond Debt Service obligation. This fund shall be nonreverting and shall be funded and operated in accordance with all legal and specific bond ordinance requirements. 
(Ord. No. 9966-09, § I, 9-28-09) 
Sec. 2-159. - Firearms training fund. 
(a)  A firearms training fund is continued, pursuant to state law. 
(b)  It shall be funded by all fees collected for handgun license applications. 
(c)  Monies shall be used by the police department exclusively to train law enforcement officers in the proper use of firearms or other law enforcement duties. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-160. - General improvement fund. 
    A general improvement fund is continued for purposes permitted under IC 36-9-17. It shall be funded and operated in accordance with statutory requirements. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-161. - Industrial development fund. 
    An industrial development fund is continued for purposes permitted under IC 36-7-13. It shall be funded and operated in accordance with statutory requirements. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-162. - Parking garages fund. 
    A parking facility fund is created for purposes permitted under IC 36-9-11-19. It shall be funded and operated in accordance with statutory requirements. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-163. - Petty cash fund. 
    A petty cash fund is established, to be administered by the Controller and to be funded and maintained at a maximum amount of seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00). It shall be operated and administered as required by IC 36-1-8-3. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-164. - Railroad relocation and reconstruction fund. 
    A railroad relocation and reconstruction fund is created to pay the City's portion of the total cost of grade separation improvement, pursuant to IC 8-6-2.1. Any monies remaining in the track elevation fund shall be transferred into this fund and remain available for the purposes so dedicated. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-165. - South Bend Regional Police Academy Fund. 
(a)  The South Bend Regional Police Academy Fund is established to collect monies received for training programs. 
(b)  Funds may be expended from the South Bend Regional Police Academy Fund for training supplies and equipment necessary to maintain the training programs. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-166. - Special events fund. 
    A special events fund is established to be used to receive monies and to pay expenses related to the operation of special events sponsored or organized by the City, including but not limited to, the Ethnic Festival, the Winter Celebration, and the World's Largest Garage Sale. Monies remaining in the fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund. Any monies remaining in the Ethnic Festival Fund shall be transferred into this fund and remain available for the purposes so dedicated. 
(Ord. No. 7108-82, § 9) 
Sec. 2-167. - Cumulative capital development fund. 
(a)  A cumulative capital development fund is established, to be used for any purposes permitted under IC 36-9-16, for capital improvements; for any purposes permitted under IC 36-9-16.5, for public ways and sidewalks; for any purposes permitted under IC 36-9-26, for sewers; for any purposes permitted under IC 36-9-17, for general improvement; for any purposes permitted under IC 36-8-14, for firefighting building and equipment and police radios; for any purposes permitted under IC 36-10-4-36, for parks; and for any purposes permitted under IC 36-9-16-2, for public buildings and rights-of-way. 
(b)  Notwithstanding uses permitted under subsection (a) above, funds accumulated in the cumulative capital development fund may be spent for purposes other than those purposes stated in subsection (a), provided that the purpose of the expenditure is to protect the public health, welfare or safety in an emergency situation which demands immediate action. Funds may be spent under the authority of this subsection only after the Mayor issues a declaration that the public health, welfare or safety is in immediate danger that requires the expenditure of money in the fund and files notice of such emergency declaration with the Board of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 7486-85, § 1) 
Sec. 2-168. - Haz-mat fund. 
(a)  The South Bend Haz-Mat Fund is established to receive monies generated by the South Bend Fire Department's response to hazardous materials incidents. 
(b)  The monies accumulated in this fund may be expended for the replacement, repair or purchase of haz-mat equipment, for training and supplies and to defray the expense of haz-mat related activities. 
(c)  Monies remaining in the fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 7748-87, § 1) 
Sec. 2-169. - East Race Waterway promotional and development fund. 
(a)  The East Race Waterway promotional and development fund is established by a separate dedicated fund to be used to receive monies, by way of donation. All sums of monies so collected and deposited in said separate dedicated fund shall be used solely for the purpose of promotion and developing the East Race Waterway. Monies remaining in the fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund. 
(b)  Any and all interest earned on the monies deposited in said dedicated fund shall remain in the fund. 
(Ord. No. 7886-88, § 1) 
Sec. 2-169.1. - Nonreverting housing maintenance fund.[38] 
(a)  The South Bend Nonreverting Housing Maintenance Fund is established to receive monies from the South Bend Housing Authority which are to be paid in lieu of real and personal property taxes by said authority. 
(b)  A maximum of twenty-thousand dollars ($20,000.00) of the City's proportionate share shall be placed in said fund by July first of each year from such funding source. The fund shall accumulate to a maximum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), with all interest earned to be placed in the general fund of the City. 
(c)  The monies accumulated in this fund may be loaned only for the short- or long-term external maintenance needs of single-family detached scattered site rental units owned by the South Bend Housing Authority, when all other funding sources available to the South Bend Housing Authority for such maintenance are exhausted. The specific criteria which must be met by the South Bend Housing Authority in order to apply for such backup funding, shall be developed by the South Bend Common Council in conjunction with the Administration and Finance Department and/or the Economic Development Department. Said criteria shall be kept on file in the Office of the City Clerk. Any application for such funds by the South Bend Housing Authority shall be reviewed by the Economic Development Department to determine the need and to recommend terms of the loan. All expenditures from this fund shall be subject to the approval of an appropriate ordinance of the Common Council. 
(d)  Monies remaining in this fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund, except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) herein. 
(e)  This fund shall be reviewed by the Common Council beginning in the year 1998. If the Council fails to specifically reaffirm or re-establish said fund by December 31, 1998, all monies remaining in this fund shall automatically revert to the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 7927-88, § 1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (38) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 7927-88, § 1, adopted Oct. 24, 1988, amended Ch. 14, Art. 14, by adding provision thereto numbered § 2-169. Inasmuch as there existed a § 2-169, the editor has redesignated the new provisions as § 2-169.1. 

Sec. 2-169.2. - Consolidated Building Department enterprise fund. 
    A Consolidated Building Department enterprise fund is established to receive monies and fees and to pay expenses including depreciation, related to the operation of the St. Joseph County/South Bend Building Department. Such fund will be subject to full accrual accounting, and will be operated in accordance with the interlocal agreement between St. Joseph County and the City of South Bend executed December 31, 1991, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 8412-93, § 1) 
Sec. 2-169.3 - Unsafe Building non-reverting fund. 
(a)  Effective January 1 2016. The Unsafe Building Fund (No. 219) is established to receive fines and fees related to the Unsafe Building law and further to receive past unused and future forfeited performance bond monies, for the sole purpose of defraying the costs and expenses incurred in board-ups and other services related to unsafe buildings administered by the City of South Bend Department of Code Enforcement. 
(b)  Monies remaining in this fund at the end of the fiscal year including all interest earned shall not revert to the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 10416-16 , § III, 1-25-16) 
Sec. 2-170. - K-9 Unit development fund. 
(a)  The K-9 Unit development fund is established by a separate dedicated fund to be used to receive monies, by way of donation. All sums of monies so collected and deposited in said separate dedicated fund shall be used solely for the purpose of development, maintenance and expansion of the K-9 Unit of the South Bend Police Department. Monies remaining in the fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund. 
(b)  Any and all interest earned on the monies deposited in said dedicated fund shall remain in the fund. 
(Ord. No. 7945-88, § 1) 
Sec. 2-170.1. - Juvenile positive assistance fund. 
(a)  The juvenile positive assistance fund is established as a separate dedicated fund to be used to receive monies from penalties paid for fines from curfew violations. All sums of monies so collected and deposited in said separate dedicated fund shall be used solely for the purposes of the Drug Abuse Resistance Education (DARE) Program and for assisting police activities in the Juvenile Aid Bureau. Monies remaining in the fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund. 
(b)  Any and all interest earned on the monies deposited in said dedicated fund shall remain in the fund. 
(Ord. No. 8135-90, § 1)

(a)  The Recreation Department nonreverting fund is established pursuant to IC 36-10-4-16.

(d)  Any and all interest earned on the monies deposited in this special fund shall remain a part of the Recreation Department nonreverting fund. 
(Ord. No. 8750-97, § 1) 
Sec. 2-170.7 - Rainy Day Fund #102. 
(a)  Establishment of fund. A new fund is established within the Civil City of South Bend to be known as the rainy day fund, designated as Fund #102. [39] 
(b)  Purpose of fund. The rainy day fund is established in order to set aside monies which can be used to meet unanticipated expenses that cannot be funded from existing appropriations, to meet cash flow needs between biannual distribution of property tax receipts and other periodic revenue distributions, for bridging a gap caused by an unexpected revenue shortfall or significant delay in receiving revenue, and for any other City purpose or need consistent with or permitted by state law. 
(c)  Sources of revenues. The Rainy Day Fund #102 shall be used exclusively as the repository of unused and unencumbered funds which may be distributed to the City of South Bend under IC 6-3.5-6-17.3, which addresses the distribution of excess County option income tax dollars; as well as IC 36-1-8-5 which addresses funds raised by a general or special tax levy which permits transfer of such funds into a rainy day fund and any other source allowed by the laws of the State of Indiana or which does not prohibit transfer of money to such rainy day fund. 
(d)  Appropriation required. The funds deposited into the Rainy Day Fund #102 shall be subject to the same appropriation process as other funds that receive tax money; however, before making an appropriation from Rainy Day Fund #102, the Common Council shall be required to make a finding that the proposed use of such monies is consistent with the overall intent and purposes of this fund. 
(e)  Maximum amount. In any fiscal year, the City may transfer an amount not to exceed ten (10) percent of the political subdivision's annual civil city budget for the fiscal year to the Rainy Day Fund #102. 
(f)  Interest earned. Any interest earned on monies in the Rainy Day Fund #102 shall be retained by the Rainy Day Fund #102. 
(g)  Statutory limitations. The City shall have, in all other respects, the authority and limitations with regard to its Rainy Day Fund #102 as prescribed by IC 36-1-8-5.1, which addresses the establishment of a rainy day fund by a political subdivision and its uses. 
(h)  Amendment and termination. The Rainy Day Fund #102 shall continue until amended or terminated by ordinance. Unless indicated otherwise by ordinance, the proceeds of this fund at termination shall be deposited into the City's general fund. 
(Ord. No. 9509-04, § I) 
Footnotes: 
--- (39) --- 
State Law reference- IC 36-1-8-5.1 authorizes the establishment of a rainy day. 

Sec. 2-170.8. - Levy excess fund. 
(a)  The levy excess fund is established within the City of South Bend pursuant to IC 6-1.1-18.5-17. 
(b)  All taxes actually collected for taxes due and payable during a particular calendar year that exceed the City of South Bend's ad valorem property tax levy as approved by the department of local government finance under IC 6-1.1-17 shall be deposited into this levy excess fund. 
(c)  The funds deposited into the City's levy excess fund shall be spent and transferred in strict conformity with the requirements and limitations prescribed by Indiana law under IC 6-1.1-18.5-7 and any amendments to that law. 
(d)  Subject to any limitations imposed by state law in IC 6-1.1-18.5-7, the City may use money in this levy excess fund for any lawful purpose for which money in any of its other funds may be used. 
(e)  If the amount of money that qualifies for deposit in this levy excess fund for a particular calendar year is less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), then no money shall be deposited in this levy excess fund for that year. 
(Ord. No. 9594-05, § I, 5-23-05) 
Sec. 2-170.9. - Palais Royale Historic Preservation Fund. 
(a)  The Palais Royale Historic Preservation Fund is established as a separate, non-reverting fund to receive monies from a two (2) percent charge assessed on all services provided in connection with the use and rental of Palais Royale facilities, and to receive monies from donations to the Palais Royale. All sums so collected and deposited in this fund shall be used for the sole purpose of assisting with the continued historic preservation, maintenance and repair of the Palais Royale building and related facilities. The funds in this account shall not be the sole source of monies for historic preservation of the Palais Royale, nor shall the existence of this fund preclude the City from providing other funds for this purpose, monies in this fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund. 
(b)  The two (2) percent historic preservation charge on services related to use and rental of the Palais Royale facilities shall not apply to fundraising events within or on the Palais Royale facilities presented by not-for-profit organizations headquartered or operating chiefly in St. Joseph County, Indiana. 
(c)  Any and all interest earned on the monies deposited in this Palais Royale Historic Preservation Fund shall remain a part of this fund to be used for the permitted purposes of the fund. 
(Ord. No. 9706-06, § I, 10-9-06) 
Sec. 2-170.10. - Morris Performing Arts Center and Palais Royale Marketing Fund. 
(a)  The Morris Performing Arts Center and Palais Royale Marketing Fund is established as a separate, nonreverting fund to receive monies from the solicitation of funds for commercial promotion sponsorships such as commercial ads on ticket envelopes and Morris marquee sponsorships; and to accept donations to the Morris Performing Arts Center and Palais Royale. All sums so collected and deposited in this fund shall be used for the sole purpose of assisting with continued promotions of and within both the Morris Performing Arts Center and Palais Royale. The funds in this account shall not be the sole source of monies for marketing/promotion of the Morris Performing Arts Center and Palais Royale, nor shall the existence of this fund preclude the City from providing other funds for this purpose. Monies in this fund at the end of the fiscal year shall not revert to the general fund. 
(b)  Any and all interest earned on the monies deposited in this Morris Performing Arts Center and Palais Royale Marketing Fund shall remain a part of this fund to be used for the permitted purposes of the fund. 
(Ord. No. 9768-07, § I, 6-25-07) 
Sec. 2-170.11. - Nonreverting private gift, donation and bequest fund. 
(a)  The private gift, donation and bequest fund is established within the City of South Bend to receive monies donated, given and/or bequeathed to the City of South Bend by private, nongovernmental persons including corporations, partnerships and similar entities. 
(b)  The Controller shall use all monies deposited into this fund for the reasonable purpose(s) designated by the donor, if any, to the extent feasible, and any terms and/or conditions attached to the gift, donation and bequest shall be reviewed and approved by the City Attorney. The Common Council may reject any gifts. 
(c)  The Controller shall deposit monies qualifying for this fund in the manner prescribed by IC 5-13-6-1 et seq., as if they were public funds, and may invest those monies as provided by the IC 5-13-9-1 et seq., with any interest deposited into this fund. 
(d)  Appropriation of monies in this fund, whether or not designated by the donor for a specific purpose, shall require approval by the Common Council. 
(e)  The Controller shall provide the Common Council annually with a list of all gifts, donations or bequests received and the amount of each. 
(f)  The monies deposited in this fund shall remain in the fund and shall not revert to the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 9870-08, § I, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 2-170.12. - Nonreverting loss recovery fund. 
(a)  The loss recovery fund is established within the City of South Bend to receive compensatory or exemplary damage payments from third parties arising from loss or damage to City tangible or intangible property. 
(b)  The Controller shall use all monies deposited into this fund for reasonable costs arising from the covered loss including repair or replacement of tangible property, administrative costs of obtaining the loss recovery, enhancement or improvement of City services related to the loss, or for any other reasonable purpose. 
(c)  The Controller shall deposit monies qualifying for this fund in the manner prescribed by IC 5-13-6-1 et seq., as if they were public funds, and may invest those monies as provided by the IC 5-13-9-1 et seq., with any interest deposited into this fund. 
(d)  Appropriation of monies in this fund, shall require approval by the Common Council. 
(e)  The Controller shall provide the Common Council annually with a list of all loss claims recovered by the City from third parties distributed to this fund, and the amount of each such loss recovery. 
(f)  The monies deposited in this fund shall remain in the fund and shall not revert to the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 9890-08, § I, 12-8-08) 
Sec. 2-170.13. - Take home vehicle fund. 
(a)  The Police Take Home Vehicle Fund (#278) is established within the City of South Bend, to receive monies collected from South Bend Police Department Officers participating in the City's Take Home Vehicle Program. 
(b)  The City shall use all monies deposited into this fund to pay the costs and expenses associated with claims arising from use of program vehicles occurring while officers are not on duty. 
(c)  If the police take home vehicle program should cease to exist, then all monies in this police take home vehicle fund shall remain within this fund for a period of at least two (2) years following the program cessation, to be used for fund purposes, at which time the fund can be closed. Any monies remaining in the fund upon closure shall be used only for general public safety purposes. 
(d)  As of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives, the balance of police take home car payroll deductions in liability insurance #226 shall be transferred to Fund #278. Upon completion of the transfer, the Controller shall notify the Council of the exact dollar amount transferred. 
(Ord. No. 9919-09, §§ I, II, 4-27-09)

ARTICLE 15. - DESIGNATION OF IMPACT AREAS 

Sec. 2-171. - Board of Public Works action. 
(a)  Whenever the Board of Public Works finds that an area within the City of South Bend meets the criteria established under this section, it may recommend, by resolution, that the South Bend Common Council designate that area to be an impact area for the planned use of community development block grant funds. 
(b)  Before making the finding in subsection (a), above, the Board shall require the Division of Community Development to prepare: 
(1)  Maps and plats showing the boundaries of the area, the location of the various parcels of property, streets, alleys and other features of relevance within the area, or a description of the general boundaries of the area by its location in relation to public ways, streams, or otherwise, as determined by the Board; and 
(2)  Objectively determinable signs of physical deterioration in the area, in the form of a substantial number of deteriorating or dilapidating buildings or improvements, together with comparisons against objective criteria, listed in subsection (c) below for the land use, or uses, of that individual area. 
(c)  Objective criteria to be used in establishing whether or not an area has objectively determinable signs of deterioration shall include the following, for the particular land use or uses within the area: 
(1)  Residential land use: 
a.  Substandard structures or units; 
b.  Age of housing; 
c.  Vacancy rates, percent or number of vacant structures; 
d.  Renter/owner ratio; 
e.  Substantial code violations; 
f.  Population losses compared with the metropolitan statistical area; 
g.  Income range of residents, percentage of low and moderate income residents; 
h.  Deteriorated or dilapidated buildings and improvements; 
i.  Infrastructure condition. 
(2)  Commercial land use: 
a.  Substandard structures or units; 
b.  Age of structures; 
c.  Vacancy rates, percent or number of vacant structures; 
d.  Condition of buildings; 
e.  Substantial code violations; 
f.  Character of occupancy; 
g.  Underutilization of structures/land; 
h.  Parking conditions, parking availability; 
i.  Deteriorating or vacant upper level housing units; 
j.  Re-use capabilities of structures; 
k.  Need surrounding market potential of neighborhood; 
l.  Cessation of growth, as demonstrated by lack of new businesses, rehabilitation and sales expansion; 
m.  Income range of residents, employees, percent of low and moderate income jobs available; 
n.  Deteriorated or dilapidated buildings and improvements; 
o.  Infrastructure condition. 
(3)  Industrial land use: 
a.  Substandard structures or units; 
b.  Age of structures; 
c.  Vacancy rates, percent or number of vacant structures; 
d.  Condition of buildings; 
e.  Substantial code violations; 
f.  Character of occupancy; 
g.  Underutilization of structures/land; 
h.  Parking conditions, parking availability; 
i.  Re-use capabilities of structures; 
j.  Cessation of growth, as demonstrated by lack of new industry, rehabilitation and expansion; 
k.  Income range of residents, employees, percent of low and moderate income jobs available; 
l.  Deteriorated or dilapidated buildings and improvements; 
m.  Infrastructure condition; 
n.  Existence of public health hazards, particularly environmental and pollution hazards; 
o.  Employment loss compared to the metropolitan statistical area; 
p.  Employment potential. 
(d)  In addition to the criteria listed in subsection (c) above, the Board may consider other information presented by the Division of Community Development relating to deteriorating conditions, such as the existence of vacant lots or acres of vacant land within the area, tax delinquent property within the area, the number of new building permits issued in the area, as compared with other similar land use areas within the City, and other factors unique to the area which impair development. 
(e)  Upon receipt of the report from the Division of Community Development with regard to the proposed impact area, the Board shall examine the evidence in the report and shall hold a public hearing to receive other evidence. Following the hearing, the Board shall determine whether or not the area meets the criteria for designation as an impact area for planned use of community development block grant funds. 
(Ord. No. 7372-84, § 1) 
Sec. 2-172. - Common Council action. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a resolution from the Board of Public Works recommending the designation of an area as an impact area under this article, together with copies of documents considered by the Board in making its finding, the Common Council shall consider the area and shall determine whether use of community development block grant funds within that area will be of public use and benefit and in furtherance of the City's plan for use of such funds. 
(b)  If the Council determines that such funds should be used in the area recommended by the Board, it shall pass a resolution designating the area an impact area for use of community development block grant funds. 
(Ord. No. 7372-84, § 1) 
Sec. 2-173. - Effect of designation. 
    The Council's determination shall be final and shall permit the use of community development block grant funds within that area as a "slum or blighted area" under local law; provided, however, that any use of such funds must meet any and all other requirements under Federal, State and local law. 
(Ord. No. 7372-84, § 1) 
Sec. 2-174. - Term of designation. 
    Any designation of an area under this section shall be effective from and after the date of the Council's action for a period of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 7372-84, § 1) 
Secs. 2-175-2-196. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 16. - INSURANCE 

Sec. 2-197. - Board of Public Works: authority to purchase insurance by competitive proposals; procedure. 
(a)  The Board of Public Works shall have the authority to purchase insurance to cover the liability of the City as may be necessary to carry out the provisions and intent of this Code. 
(b)  Effective immediately all contracts for liability insurance coverage shall be subject to competitive proposals every three (3) years. 
(c)  Complete specifications for such insurance shall be approved by a committee whose members shall include the City Attorney, Controller, Deputy Controller and Chairman of the Common Council's Committee on Administration and Finance. Specifications shall be filed with the Clerk of the Board. 
(d)  The Board shall cause to be published for two (2) weeks, once each week, in a newspaper of general circulation published in the City, a notice informing the public and prospective bidders of the general nature of the insurance coverage needed and of the facts that complete specifications are on file in such office, and calling for proposals for such coverage by a day not earlier than thirty (30) days after the last of such publications. 
(e)  The Board shall require each bidder to file with such Board an affidavit that such bidder has not directly or indirectly entered into any combination, collusion, undertaking or agreement with any other bidder or other person with reference to such bidding, in any way or manner whatever. 
(f)  Upon proper money appropriation by ordinance, the Board shall, if a satisfactory proposal is received, let such contract to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder. 
(Ord. No. 8436-93, § 2) 
Secs. 2-198-2-204. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 17. - CHARGES FOR DIRECT CITY EXPENDITURES 

Sec. 2-205. - Fees charged for legal advertisements.[24] 
(a)  All petitioners seeking voluntary annexations, vacation of public ways, or rezonings, except those rezonings petitioned for by the Area Plan Commission or a member of the Common Council, shall remit the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) at the time of filing said petition. Said sum is nonrefundable and shall be used to fulfill all legal advertisement requirements of such proceedings incurred by the City. 
(b)  All petitioners seeking tax abatements or impact area designations, except those impact areas petitioned for by a member of the Common Council, shall remit the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) at the time of filing said petition. Said sum is nonrefundable and shall be used to fulfill all legal advertisement requirements of such proceedings incurred by the City. 
(Ord. No. 6836-80, § 1; Ord. No. 7167-83, § 1; Ord. No. 7534-85, § 1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Reserved. 24 Editor's note: At the request of the city, the fees in this section have been changed from $100.00 to $150.00 and $150.00 to $250.00 to reflect the changes made in § 18-53.8 by Ord. No. 8076-90, § I and § 2-84.7 by Ord. No. 8065, § 1, respectively. 
Cross reference: Tax abatement procedures, § 2-76 et seq. 

Sec. 2-206. - Deposit required prior to advertisement for sale of land. 
(a)  A per parcel deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be required of any party (except for other governmental entities and not-for-profit corporations qualified under 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code) who requests that the City sell a particular parcel of land prior to advertisement. 
(b)  The deposit shall be collected by the Department of Public Works at the time of the request and shall be applied as follows: 
(1)  If the City determines for whatever reason that it cannot or should not sell the property, the entire deposit shall be returned to the requesting party. 
(2)  If the property is put up for sale and no bid is received, the deposit shall become the property of the City. 
(3)  If the property is sold to someone other than the requesting party, the deposit shall be returned to the requesting party. 
(4)  If the property is sold to the requesting party, the deposit shall be applied to the purchase price. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit the Board of Public Works from initiating the advertisement of property for sale. 
(Ord. No. 9395-03, § 1) 
Secs. 2-207-2-209. - Reserved.

CHAPTER 3 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- As to advertising auctions by use of bellman, see § 7-32; as to vehicle used for advertising, see § 20-75; as to use of vehicles for advertising, see § 15-14; as to affixing posters and advertising material to trees and shrubs, see § 19-3. 
State Law reference- Regulation of billboards, IC 8-23-20-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE 1. - ADVERTISING MATERIALS REGULATIONS 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  As used in this Article: 
(1)  Advertising matter means, any written or printed card, circular, coupon, pamphlet or folder intended for general distribution, except newspapers. 
(2)  Sample means, any package or parcel of merchandise intended for general distribution and for which no charge is made. 
(Code 1962, § 3-1) 
Sec. 3-2. - Distribution; general requirement. 
    No person shall distribute any advertising matter, circular or sample in the City except as provided in this Article. 
(Code 1962, § 3-2) 
Sec. 3-3. - Distribution of advertising matter prohibited; exception. 
(a)  No person shall throw, scatter or distribute or cause to be thrown, scattered or distributed any poster, sign, card, pamphlet, sample of merchandise or other advertising device upon any sidewalk, street, lane, alley, public ground or other public place or upon any private lot or porch or throw into or upon or attach to any vehicle any advertising matter or sample within the City. 
(b)  Any person may distribute such advertising matter or samples to private residences, offices or mercantile establishments if the same is handed in at the door or securely fastened to prevent it from being blown or scattered about. 
(Code 1962, § 3-3) 
Sec. 3-4. - Leaving advertising matter on property prohibited. 
    No person shall, when removing any old poster, card or other advertising device leave or deposit the same upon any public or private sidewalk, street, alley, lot or ground within the City. 
(Code 1962, § 3-5) 
Sec. 3-5. - Advertisements on trees and poles prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall post, paste or in any way attach or affix any bill, notice, announcement or other advertisement to any tree located in any alley, street or other public place in the City or upon or to any pole used for telegraph, telephone, electric light, fire alarm or any other purpose authorized by the Council. 
(b)  The provisions of Subsection (a) shall not apply to the posting of any notice or order of any court, nor to the posting of any legal notice required or authorized by law. 
(Code 1962, § 3-6) 
Sec. 3-6. - Advertisements on public pavement and buildings prohibited. 
    No person shall paste, paint, place or fasten, in any manner, any poster, sign, card, sample package or other advertising matter or device onto any public sidewalk, curb or pavement or onto any public building or other public improvement within the City. 
(Code 1962, § 3-7) 
Sec. 3-7. - Advertising secondhand or defective merchandise; exception.[2] 
(a)  No person shall in any newspaper, magazine, circular, form letter or any open publication published, distributed or circulated in the City, or on any billboard, car, label or other advertising medium, or by means of any other method of advertising, advertise, call attention to or give publicity to the sale of any merchandise, which: 
(1)  Is secondhand or used merchandise; 
(2)  Is defective in any manner; 
(3)  Consists of articles or units or parts known as "seconds"; 
(4)  Is blemished merchandise; or, 
(5)  Has been rejected by the manufacturer thereof as not first class. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply if there is conspicuously displayed directly in connection with the name and description of such merchandise and each specified article, unit or part thereof, a direct and unequivocal statement, phrase or word which will clearly indicate that such merchandise or each article, unit or part thereof so advertised is secondhand, used, defective or consists of "seconds" or is blemished merchandise or has been rejected by the manufacturer thereof, as the fact may be. 
(Code 1962, § 3-8) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Deception, IC 35-43-5-3. 

Sec. 3-8. - Advertising by crying aloud or carrying banners prohibited. 
    No person shall cry aloud upon the streets of the City or in the doorways of any place of business along the street advertising any commercial business whatever or carry or have carried along and over the streets of the City any signs, banners or displays of any kind or description intended to advertise any commercial business. 
(Code 1962, § 3-10) 
Sec. 3-9. - Advertising with music for commercial purposes prohibited. 
    No person shall make, cause or permit to be made any music upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place for the purpose of attracting attention to or soliciting trade or business on behalf of any business place. 
Sec. 3-10. - Advertisements placed on automobiles prohibited; exceptions. 
    No person shall place or deposit or in any manner affix or cause to be placed or deposited or affixed to any automobile or other vehicle or other automotive vehicle any handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever not provided by law, unless he is the owner thereof, or without first having secured in writing the consent of the owner. 
(Code 1962, § 3-11) 
ARTICLE 2. - ILLUMINATED SIGNS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- As to electricity generally, see Chapter 8 of this Code; as to signs, see also Chapter 6 of this Code. 
State Law reference- Unauthorized signs, signals, etc., IC 9-21-4-4 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8793-97, § I, adopted June 9, 1997, repealed Div. 1, §§ 3-11-3-20, which pertained to permits and regulations for illuminated signs, and derived from Code 1962, §§ 21-1-21-10. 

Secs. 3-11-3-20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION AND HEIGHT SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 3-21. - Flat signs minimum height. 
    Illuminated signs flat against a building may be erected at entrance door height if the entire sign box is flat against the building wall; otherwise, the sign shall clear the sidewalk by nine (9) feet. 
(Code 1962, § 21-11) 
Sec. 3-22. - Prohibited attachment of signs. 
(a)  Flat signs shall not be supported by or placed over the parapet of a wall. 
(b)  No sign shall be attached to or supported by a chimney or water tank. 
(Code 1962, § 21-12) 
Sec. 3-23. - Projecting signs; maximum height. 
    The overall vertical dimension of an illuminated projecting sign shall not exceed sixty (60) feet. 
(Code 1962, § 21-13) 
Sec. 3-24. - Anchorage and height of signs above public way. 
(a)  Illuminated signs projecting over public property shall: 
(1)  Be supported by a structure anchored wholly within the lot lines; 
(2)  Have the lowest part overhanging the public way at least ten (10) feet above such public way; provided, that such sign does not project within two (2) feet of the curb line; 
(3)  If installed over an alley, be at least eighteen (18) feet above the roadway. 
(Code 1962, § 21-14) 
Sec. 3-25. - Design requirements. 
(a)  The design of the illuminated sign shall be such: 
(1)  To afford ample strength and rigidity; 
(2)  To render the box practically weatherproof; 
(3)  To enclose all terminals and wiring; and, 
(4)  To provide drainage for each compartment. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-26. - Joint requirements. 
(a)  Where joints occur in a metal box or drum, they shall be riveted or bolted, and lap type. The lap shall be sufficient for weatherproofing. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-27. - Openings in box or drum. 
    All openings in the box or drum shall be provided with covers arranged to lock securely. Unless hinged, the covers shall be secured to the sign box by a noncorrosive chain. When openings occur in the top section of the box or drum, an upstanding flange shall be provided around the entire opening. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-28. - Faces, boxes and backs. 
(a)  Approved plastic may be used for sign faces, but not as a supporting means. 
(b)  If metal is used in the construction of illuminated sign faces on box type signs or letters, it shall be not less than No. 24 U.S. gauge, twenty-five hundredths (.025) of an inch. Metal used in faces of signs other than box type shall be not less than No. 18 U.S. gauge five hundredths (.050) of an inch. Metal shall be used for construction of backs of flat signs and shall be not less than No. 24 U.S. gauge, twenty-five hundredths (.025) of an inch. Metal shall be used in the construction of box or drum, i.e., that section to which the sign faces are attached, and shall be not less than No. 20 U.S. sheet metal gauge, thirty seven hundredths (.037) of an inch. The box or drum shall be galvanized steel. 
(c)  Drainage shall be provided by means of one (1) or more holes, each not larger than one (1) inch or less than one-quarter (1/4) inch in diameter. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-29. - Reinforcement of faces. 
    Metal faces of all illuminated signs more than two (2) feet wide shall be reinforced on the inside with galvanized iron stiffening channels or angles and also stayed or braced to the frame or opposite side, such stays or braces to be so placed that all surface areas of ten (10) square feet are so reinforced. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
_____
Sec. 3-30. - Framework requirements. 
    All signs having an area of twelve (12) or more square feet of one (1) face shall have an approved structural framework of galvanized steel angles or the equivalent in strength to be not less than specified in the following table: 
AREA OF FACE PROJECTING SIGNS SINGLE FACED SIGNS 12 to 20 sq. ft. 11/2 × 11/2 × 3/16 11/2 × 11/2 × 3/16 21 to 40 sq. ft. 2 × 2 × 3/16 11/2 × 2 × 3/16 41 to 70 sq. ft. 2 × 2 × 1/4 2 × 2 × 3/16 Larger than above 21/2 × 21/2 × 1/4 2 × 2 × 1/4  
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
_____
Sec. 3-31. - Intermediate brace; specifications. 
(a)  Signs of ten (10) or more lineal feet shall have an intermediate brace for every five (5) lineal feet. 
(b)  If the frame is made of angle larger than one and one-half by one and one-half by three-sixteenth of an inch (11/2 × 11/2 × 3/16 ), the next size angle may be used as a brace. All connections between framework members shall be made with galvanized machine bolts not less than three-eighths ( 3/8 ) inch in diameter or riveted. Gusset plates or equivalent shall be used in making these connections where the area of the sign is greater than forty (40) square feet. 
(c)  Metal sign faces shall be bolted, screwed or riveted to the flange of the drum with a maximum distance of eight (8) inches on center. If riveted, suitable tinned or cherry rivets shall be used. If bolted, brass or galvanized bolts not less than eight thirty-seconds ( 8/32 ) shall be used. If screwed, suitable sheet metal screws shall be used. 
(d)  All irons provided for attachments to the building, the attachment of guys and lift chains and the attachment to a crane shall be directly connected to the structural framework of the sign. 
(e)  Signs built in more than one (1) section shall have provision for connecting sections during the course of erection so that the entire structural framework will act as a completely fabricated and assembled unit. Each section shall be so constructed that the interior is accessible for maintenance and inspection. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-32. - Glass in box type sign. 
    The glass in a box type sign shall be double strength or plate glass. The area of any one (1) piece of glass in each face of a sign over public property shall not exceed eight (8) square feet where double strength glass is used, nor eighteen (18) square feet where plate glass is used. Each such piece shall be supported by a separate frame. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-33. - Catwalk and ladder requirements. 
(a)  Catwalks for maintenance purposes on signs and sign structures shall be constructed of metal. Ladders on sign structures shall be at least fifteen (15) inches wide. Ladders on signs shall be metal and not less than ten (10) inches wide. 
(b)  Horizontal projecting signs, the bottoms of which are more than twenty-eight (28) feet above the public way, shall be provided with catwalks and handrails. 
(c)  Horizontal flat signs, the bottoms of which are more than twenty-eight (28) feet above the public way, shall be provided with catwalks and handrails, unless signs can be maintained by means other than ladders supported from the way. 
(d)  Vertical signs, the bottoms of which are more than twenty-eight (28) feet above the public way, or with a vertical dimension of more than twenty-eight (28) feet, shall have ladders the full vertical distance of the sign. In addition, all signs in the above category which are more than four (4) feet wide shall be provided with a steel structure at the top of sign for maintenance purposes. 
(e)  Structures over twelve (12) feet high used primarily to support illuminated signs shall be provided with ladders extending from roof or ground to the top of structure, and, in addition, shall have catwalks so that all parts of the display are accessible for maintenance purposes. 
(Code 1962, § 21-13) 
Sec. 3-34. - Signs with moving parts, clocks or thermometers. 
    Signs employing the use of moving parts for animated action, as well as clocks and thermometers, shall be designed so that the driving mechanism, the driven linkage and the supporting bearings are securely anchored to the main steel structure of the sign, and the supports for the movable portions of the display shall be calculated to support its weight, plus the maximum wind pressure to which the movable portions may be subjected. Mechanical motions having an arc of rotation of less than sixty (60) degrees rotation shall be accomplished through the use of slip rings. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-35. - Plastic materials; uses. 
    Approved plastic materials, such as acrylic plastic or its equivalent, may be used on signs under the conditions set forth in Section 3-36 to Section 3-45. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-36. - Plastic temperature limitations. 
    The plastic material shall not be subjected to a temperature higher than one hundred and forty-nine (149) degrees, Fahrenheit, unless such material is certified by the manufacturer to be special heat resistant material, in which case the temperature shall not exceed one hundred and eighty (180) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-37. - Plastic material adjacent to lighting and wiring. 
(a)  The sign shall be constructed so that the plastic material will not come in contact with gas tubes or other source of illumination. It shall be kept at least two (2) inches from the nearest incandescent lamp. 
(b)  The wiring and current carrying parts, other than lampholders, shall be enclosed in metal. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-38. - Plastic material in metal frame. 
    When plastic material is mounted in a metal frame, proper provision shall be made for the difference in expansion between the plastic and the frame. One-sixteenth ( 1/16 ) inch total clearance for each twelve (12) inches or fraction thereof of the dimension perpendicular to the mounted edge shall be provided in the mounting system. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-39. - Plastic material held by flanges, troughs, channels or clips. 
(a)  When plastic is held in place by flanges, troughs, channels or clips, these means of attachment shall overlap the plastic by not less than three-eighths ( 3/8 ) of an inch for panels up to twelve (12) inches wide; for panels over twelve (12) inches wide and up to twenty-four (24) inches wide, seven-sixteenths ( 7/16 ) of an inch; from twenty-four (24) inches to thirty-six (36) inches wide, one-half (1/2) inch; thirty-six (36) inches to forty-eight (48) inches wide, nine-sixteenths ( 9/16 ) of an inch; over forty-eight (48) inches, three-fourths (3/4) of an inch. 
(b)  Flanges, troughs or continuous channels shall be made of galvanized sheet metal, copper or aluminum, not less than twenty (20) gauge U.S. standard in thickness. Where clips are used for attachment, they shall be made of noncorrosive spring type material, such as phosphor bronze or equivalent, the thickness of which shall not be less than thirty-two hundredths (.032) of an inch in thickness. Each clip shall not be less than two (2) inches wide, and clips, bolts, screws or rivets shall be spaced on not less than seven (7) inch centers around the entire periphery of the plastic. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-40. - Washers required in certain instances to fasten plastic material. 
    When bolts, screws or rivets are used to fasten plastic material to a metal frame, washers shall be placed under the heads of the bolts, screws or rivets. These washers shall be of metal or a noncorrosive material and have an outside diameter of not less than six (6) times the diameter of the screw being used. Washers shall be not less than thirty-two hundredths (.032) of an inch in thickness. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-41. - Fastening devices used with plastic material. 
    Undue pressure of fastening devices against the plastic material should be avoided by use of suitable gasket material, spring tension or adequate clearance to allow for expansion. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-42. - Support of removable plastic panels required. 
    Removable plastic panels not fastened to the frame or supported on all edges shall be supported on their longest dimension by troughs on two (2) opposite edges. Where such removable panels are made in several sections, the adjacent edges shall be joined together where the adjacent edges exceed twelve (12) inches in length by fastenings directly supported to the frame of the sign. Such fastenings to be not less than twelve (12) inches on centers. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-43. - Plastic material strength and flexibility requirements. 
(a)  The plastic decorations, faces, panels and letter facings shall either: 
(1)  Be demonstrated to be of sufficient thickness or so formed or supported as to withstand twenty-five (25) pounds uniform load per square foot without coming in contact with gas tubes or any other source of illumination and without coming within two (2) inches of an incandescent lamp; or 
(2)  Be of a thickness not less than that indicated in the following table: 
Minor Dimension of Exposed Plastic Sheet Flat Panels Minimum Nominal Thickness of Plastic 12? .060? 18? .080? 24? .100? 30? .125? 48? .187? 60? .250?  
(b)  Plastic sign faces, panels and decorations, the dimensions of which are fixed by reference to the table in Subsection (a) shall be so stayed, braced or supported as to prevent contact with gas tubes or any other source of illumination and so to prevent deflection of a point within two (2) inches of an incandescent lamp. The dimension between supported edges shall be considered to be minor dimension for purposes of the table in Subsection (a). 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-44. - Plastic sheets used as supports. 
    Plastic sheets shall not be used as a supporting means for current carrying parts or sources of illumination. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-45. - Plastic letters or characters; use and limitation. 
    Approved solid type or hollow plastic letters or characters may be used, provided they are not used as a raceway. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
Sec. 3-46. - Safety precautions required. 
    Facilities for proper protection of the public shall be provided during the erection or maintenance of all signs. 
(Code 1962, § 21-15) 
DIVISION 3. - MANNER OF HANGING SIGNS 

Sec. 3-47. - Signs to be hung; manner. 
    All illuminated signs shall be hung in the manner prescribed in this Division. 
(Code 1962, § 21-18) 
Sec. 3-48. - Hanging flat signs. 
    Flat signs shall be anchored below the roof line; except, that additional support, other than a chain, may be provided over a parapet to the roof. 
(Code 1962, § 21-18) 
_____
Sec. 3-49. - Projecting signs; chain and cable supports; fastenings. 
(a)  All projecting signs shall have standard chain or cable supports and fastenings to the building, as shown in the following table: 
Weight of Sign 
(Pounds) Number of Chains or Cables Trade Size of Chains or Cables Fastening to Wall Up to 75 ..... 1  4/0 Two expansion bolts per chain. 76 to 150 ..... 2  4/0 Two expansion bolts per chain. 151 to 400 ..... 2  8/0 One bolt through wall or equivalent. 401 to 1000 ..... 2 10/0 Two bolts through wall or equivalent.  
_____
(b)  Fastenings shall be installed so that attached supports or guys make an angle of forty-five degrees (45°) or greater with the sign. Where machine or lag screws enter strong structure anchorages, they shall be considered as equivalent to a bolt through the wall. Expansion bolts shall be not less than three-eighths ( 3/8 ) of an inch in diameter, and enter woodwork not less than three (3) inches. 
(c)  No supporting chain or cable shall be attached back of the center of gravity of the sign, except in the case of the rear supports of vertical signs. 
(d)  Each lift chain or cable shall be capable of carrying the sign alone. Fastenings for signs, supports or guys shall not be attached to parapet walls and not less than eight (8) inches from the corner of the building. 
(Code 1962, § 21-18) 
Sec. 3-50. - Hanging projecting signs. 
(a)  Projecting signs exceeding one hundred (100) square feet in area of one (1) face shall be rigidly hung on beams. 
(b)  Separate projecting signs hung so as to appear as one (1) sign shall be rigidly hung on beams if the total area of all faces on one (1) side of the sign exceeds one hundred (100) square feet. 
(Code 1962, § 21-18) 
_____
Sec. 3-51. - Standard chain, cable side guys or rigid base supports; specifications. 
(a)  All projecting signs shall have standard chain or cable side guys or rigid brace supports as shown in the following tables:
