(d)  Public hearing. During the extended review period and before taking action on the requested rate increase, the Board of Public Works shall hold at least one public hearing at which interested person may express their views and record objections. 
(e)  Objections. An interested person who wishes to make an objection to the proposed rate increase may request the Clerk of the Board of Public Works to record the objection during the public hearing or may submit the objection in writing anytime before the decision resolution is adopted. In order for an objection to be made a part of the record, the objector must provide the Clerk of the Board of Public Works with the objector's name and address. 
(f)  Delayed determination. If the Board of Public Works is unable to make a final determination concerning a requested rate increase within the extended time period, the cable operator may put the increase into effect, subject to subsequent refund if the Board of Public Works later issues a decision disapproving any portion of the increase. 
(g)  Price cap analysis. If a cable operator presents its request for a rate increase as being in compliance with the FCC's price cap, the Board of Public Works shall review the rate using the price cap analysis in accordance with the standard form authorized by the FCC. Based on the Board of Public Works' findings, the basic cable rates shall be established as follows: 
(1)  If the proposed basic cable rate increase is within the price cap established by the FCC, the proposed rates shall become the new basic cable rates. 
(2)  If the proposed basic cable rate increase exceeds the price cap established by the FCC, the Board of Public Works shall disapprove the proposed rate increase and order an increase that is in compliance the price cap. 
(h)  Cost-of-service showing. If a cable operator submits a cost-of-service showing in an attempt to justify a rate increase above the price cap, the Board of Public Works will review the submission pursuant to the FCC standards for cost-of-service review. The Board of Public Works may approve a rate increase above the price cap if the cable operator makes the necessary showing; however, a cost-of-service determination resulting in a rate below the price cap or below the cable operator's then current rate will prescribe the cable operator's new rate. 
(i)  Decision. The Board of Public Works' decision concerning the requested rate increase shall be adopted by formal resolution. If a rate increase proposed by a cable operator is disapproved in whole or in part, or if objections were made by other parties to the proposed rate increase, the resolution must state the reason for the decision. Objections may be made at the public hearing by a person requesting the Clerk of the Board of Public Works to record the objection or may be submitted in writing at anytime before the decision resolution is adopted. 
(j)  Refunds. 
(1)  The Board of Public Works may order refunds of subscribers' rate payments with interest if: 
a.  The Board of Public Works was unable to make a decision within the extended time period as described in paragraph (c) above; and 
b.  The cable operator implemented the rate increase at the end of the extended review period; and 
c.  The board of Public Works determines that the rate increase as submitted exceeds the applicable price cap or that the cable operator failed to justify the rate increase by a cost-of-service showing, and the Board of Public Works disapproves any portion of the rate increase. 
(2)  The method for paying any refund and the interest rate will be in accordance with FCC regulations as directed in the Board of City Works' decision resolution. 
(k)  Appeal. The Board of Public Works' decision concerning rates for the basic service tier or associated equipment, may be appealed to the FCC in accordance with applicable federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 8464-94, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 7-17. - Cable operator information. 
(a)  City may require. 
(1)  In those cases when the cable operator has submitted initial rates or proposed an increase that exceeds the reasonable rate standard, the Board of Public Works may require the cable operator to produce information in addition to that submitted, including proprietary information, if needed to make a rate determination. In these cases, a cable operator may request the information be kept confidential in accordance with this section. 
(2)  In cases where initial or proposed rates comply with the reasonable rate standard, the Board of Public Works may request additional information only in order to document that the cable operator's rates are in accord with the standard. 
(b)  Request for confidentiality. 
(1)  A cable operator submitting information to the Board of Public Works may request in writing that the information not be made routinely available for public inspection. A copy of the request shall be attached to and cover all of the information and all copies of the information to which its applies. 
(2)  If feasible, the information to which the request applies shall be physically separated from any information to which the request does not apply. If this is not feasible, the portion of the information to which the request applies shall be identified. 
(3)  Each request shall contain a statement of the reasons for withholding inspection and a statement of the facts upon which those reasons are based. 
(4)  Casual requests which do not comply with the requirements of this subsection, shall not be considered. 
(c)  Board of public works action. Requests which comply with the requirements of subsection (b), will be acted upon by the Board of Public Works. The Board of Public Works will grant the request if the cable operator presents by a preponderance of the evidence, a case for nondisclosure consistent with applicable federal regulations. If the request is granted, the ruling will be placed in a public file in lieu of the information withheld from public inspection. If the request does not present a case for nondisclosure and the Board of Public Works denies the request, the Board of Public Works shall take one of the following actions: 
(1)  If the information has been submitted voluntarily without any direction from the City, the cable operator may request that the City return the information without considering it. Ordinarily, the City will comply with this request. Only in the unusual instance that the public interest so requires, will the information be made available for public inspection. 
(2)  If the information was required to be submitted by the Board of Public Works, the information will be made available for public inspection. 
(d)  Appeal. If the Board of Public Works denies the request for confidentiality, the cable operator may seek review of that decision from the FCC within five (5) working days of the Board of Public Works' decision, and the release of the information will be stayed pending review. 
(Ord. No. 8464-94, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 7-18. - Automatic rate adjustments. 
(a)  Annual inflation adjustment. In accordance with FCC regulations, the cable operator may adjust its capped base per channel rate for the basic service tier annually by the final GNP-PI index. 
(b)  Other external costs. 
(1)  The FCC regulations also allow the cable operator to increase its rate for the basic service tier automatically to reflect certain external cost factors to the extent that the increase in cost of those factors exceeds the GNP-PI. These factors include retransmission consent fees, programming costs, state and local taxes applicable to the provision of cable television service and costs of franchise requirements. The total cost of an increase in a franchise fee may be automatically added to the base per channel rate, without regard to its relation to the GNP-PI. 
(2)  For all categories of external costs other than retransmission consent and franchise fees, the starting date for measuring changes in external cost for which the basic service per channel rate may be adjusted will be the date on which the basic service tier becomes subject to regulation or February 28, 1994, whichever occurs first. The permitted per channel charge may not be adjusted for costs of retransmission consent fees or changes in those fees incurred before October 6, 1994. 
(c)  Notification and review. The cable operator shall notify the Clerk of the Board of Public Works at least thirty (30) days in advance of a rate increase based on automatic adjustment items. The City will review the increase to determine whether the item or items qualify as automatic adjustments. If the City makes no objection within thirty (30) days of receiving notice of the increase, the increase may go into effect. 
(Ord. No. 8464-94, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 7-19. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Refunds. The City may order the cable operator to refund to subscribers a portion of previously paid rates under the following circumstances: 
(1)  A portion of the previously paid rates have been determined to be in excess of the permitted tier charge or above the actual cost of service; or 
(2)  The cable operator has failed to comply with a valid rate order issued by the City. 
(b)  Fines. If the cable operator fails to comply with a rate decision or refund order, the cable operator shall be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day the cable operator fails to comply. 
(Ord. No. 8464-94, § 1, 2-14-94)

ARTICLE 7. - UNDERGROUND CONDUITS 

Sec. 8-46. - Underground district designated. 
(a)  No person shall erect or permit to be erected any telephone, telegraph, electric light, cable television lines or power poles or aerial wires, appliances or structures, or to maintain or permit to be maintained any telephone, telegraph, electric light or power poles or aerial wires, appliances or structures overhead, on or over the district within the City, bounded by a line described in this section, or on or over the streets or parts of streets covered by the line designated in subsection (b). 
(b)  The prohibited area shall be as follows: Beginning at a point in the St. Joseph River where Madison Street, if extended across the St. Joseph River, would intersect the middle of such river, and running west on such extension and on Madison Street to Michigan Street; thence north on Michigan Street to Navarre Street; thence west on Navarre Street to Portage Avenue; thence south on Short Navarre and through the alley to Marion Street; thence west on Marion Street to Leland Avenue; thence southwest on Leland Avenue to Lincoln Way West to Scott Street; thence south on Scott Street to LaSalle Avenue; thence west on LaSalle Avenue to LaPorte Avenue; thence southeast on LaPorte Avenue to Washington Avenue; thence east on Washington Avenue to Chapin Street; thence south on Chapin Street to Dunn Street; thence east on Dunn Street to Scott Street; thence south on Scott Street to Railroad Street; thence east on Railroad Street to South Street; thence east on South Street to the middle of the St. Joseph River; thence northerly with the middle of such river to the place of beginning, excepting the alley between Madison Street and Marion Street. 
(Code 1962, § 30-1) 
Sec. 8-47. - Overhead wires, etc. prohibited in certain areas. 
(a)  No person shall erect or permit to be erected or to have, maintain or permit to be maintained, any aerial wires or cables running longitudinally upon the streets or parts of streets set forth in this section nor any telephone, telegraph, electric light, cable television lines or power poles within or upon the streets designated in subsection (b). 
(b)  The prohibited area shall be as follows: North Michigan Street, from Navarre Street to the railroad overpass north of the St. Joseph River; Riverside Drive from its junction with Marion Street to Lathrop Street; Portage Avenue, from its intersection with Navarre Street to the Viaduct; Lincoln Way West from Scott Street to Bendix Drive; West Washington Avenue, from LaPorte Avenue to Circle Avenue; South Michigan Street, from South Street to Chippewa Avenue; Lincoln Way East, from South Street to Ironwood Drive; East Jefferson Boulevard, from the middle of the St. Joseph River to the eastern City limits; East LaSalle Avenue, from the St. Joseph River to Eddy Street; Hill Street, from East Jefferson Boulevard to South Bend Avenue; North Shore Drive from Michigan Street to Angela Boulevard; Howard Street, from Michigan Street to St. Louis Street; St. Louis Street, from Jefferson Boulevard to Howard Street; Washington Avenue, from center of the river to Eddy Street; Colfax Avenue, from Hill Street to Eddy Street; East Western Avenue, from Michigan Street to St. Joseph Street; nor shall any poles on intersecting streets, alleys or avenues of the streets or parts of streets designated in this Section be placed or maintained nearer than thirty (30) feet of either side of the streets hereinabove named for wires crossing the abovementioned streets, which are sixty-six (66) feet or less in width and not nearer than twenty (20) feet of either side of the abovenamed streets which are over sixty-six (66) feet in width. 
(Code 1962, § 30-2) 
Sec. 8-48. - Exceptions to article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any poles, wires or cables installed as part of any street lighting installed under contract with the City. 
(Code 1962, § 30-3) 
Sec. 8-49. - Underground conduits required. 
    Wires or cables, as contemplated by this article, shall be located in conduits underground in accordance with the restrictions and regulations as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1962, § 30-4) 
Sec. 8-50. - Plans and specifications; refund; amendment. 
(a)  The company locating a conduit under the surface of any street, avenue, alley or public ground or part thereof shall, before beginning work, present to the Council a written statement specifying all streets, avenues, alleys or public grounds or parts thereof, in which conduits are to be located and the side and portions of the streets and the approximate size of the conduits proposed to be used and the distance from the surface of the street to the top of the conduit. Such statement shall be accompanied by a map, profile and specifications, which show the proposed location with reference to the street lines, and the surface of the street and the dimensions and the material of the conduit and the manholes and appliances and connections to be used therewith. 
(b)  Such map, profile and specifications shall be at once referred to the Board of Public Works and Safety for suggestion with reference to the proposed location of the conduits in respect to other improvements. The proposed location shall be changed, as may be found necessary and directed by the Council after a report from the Board of Public Works and Safety. Such map, profile or specifications shall be altered accordingly by and at the expense of the company constructing such conduit and after being corrected or changed as may be found necessary, shall, together with the original statement referred to above, be filed in the Office of the Clerk. 
(c)  The conduit shall be constructed in accordance with the statement, map, profile and specifications, but upon the application of any company constructing a conduit and the recommendation of the Board of Public Works and Safety, a change may be made in the location or material of any conduit or method of construction; provided, that such change is approved by resolution of the Council, and the company making such a change, on or before the completion of the conduits, files with the Clerk an amended statement, map, profile and specifications describing the conduit as changed. 
(Code 1962, § 30-5) 
Sec. 8-51. - Unnecessary excavations; guarding excavations; replacing pavement; liability. 
(a)  In the location, construction or repair of conduits under the provisions of this article, no excavation or obstruction shall unnecessarily be made, placed or continued. 
(b)  Any excavation or obstruction made or placed in any street, avenue, alley or public ground at any time for any purpose whatever, by the company constructing the conduit or their agents, servants or contractors, shall be properly guarded by such company. 
(c)  Any pavement at any time or for any purpose whatever torn up or displaced by such company shall be properly and speedily replaced and put in proper repair by such company under the supervision and to the acceptance of the Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(d)  Such company shall pay all damages for injuries to persons or property, of any person as well as to the City, resulting from or occasioned by, or growing out of negligence or improper construction in the laying, construction or repairing of such company's conduits or the maintenance of the same. It shall fully indemnify and save harmless the City from and against all claims, action or suits at law or in equity of any name or nature for damages to persons or property resulting from, occasioned by or growing out of the omission of such company or its servants, agents or contractors, to properly guard any excavation or obstruction at any time or for any purpose whatsoever made, placed or caused in any street, alley, avenue or public ground or the omission to properly or speedily replace and repave any opening or to keep such pavement in proper repair, so far as such repair may be made necessary by the interference of such pavement caused by the location, construction, use or repair of such conduits. 
(Code 1962, § 30-6) 
Sec. 8-52. - Supervision; restoration and repair costs. 
    All work done under the provisions of this article shall be done under the supervision and control of the Board of Public Works and Safety and its authorized agents, who shall have power to condemn and remove or cause to be removed all rejected or improper material used in restoring or repairing any street or any pavement, sidewalk or other improvement. Such repair or restoration shall be made at the expense of such company or individual. 
(Code 1962, § 30-37) 
Sec. 8-53. - Duties to move upon notice; failure to comply. 
    Any company placing wires underground in any street, avenue, alley or public ground of the City shall, upon written notice from the proper authority of the City that a local improvement or sewer or water main is to be repaired or constructed in such a manner as will necessitate the moving or altering of the conduits of such company, move or alter the same at its own expense, so as to permit the constructing or repairing of the improvement where ordered. If any such person or company fail to comply with such notice the conduits may be altered or moved by the City and the cost and expense thereof recovered from such company, except when such removal or repairs are made necessary by the carelessness or improper construction of any improvements by or for adjoining property owners. 
(Code 1962, § 30-8) 
Sec. 8-54. - Minimum distance between conduits. 
    No conduit for electric light or power wires or conductors shall be laid in the same side of any street, alley, avenue or public ground parallel with other conduits nearer than four (4) feet to such other conduits, unless otherwise permitted by the Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(Code 1962, § 30-9) 
Sec. 8-55. - Distribution of wires from conduits to buildings; use of poles, etc. 
    The distribution of wires from the conduits to buildings or other locations aboveground shall be by means of poles, the location of which, together with the manner of constructing the same and the making or provisions for the location and security of wires and the safety of life and property, shall be under the control and direction of the Board of Public Works and Safety. In all cases where it is necessary to cross any street, avenue, alley or public ground of the City for the purpose of distributing such wires, the crossing of such streets, alleys or public ground shall be in such manner as the Board of Public Works and Safety shall direct. 
(Code 1962, § 30-10) 
Sec. 8-56. - City use of wires. 
    Any owner or operator of conduits shall provide one (1) duct in each conduit laid underground for the sole use of the City, of size satisfactory to the Board of Public Works and Safety, for police and fire alarm wires, and shall give the City the right to the exclusive use of the top cross arm of every pole erected or to be erected in any part of the City. 
(Code 1962, § 30-11) 
Sec. 8-57. - Inspection requirements; issuance of certificates; reinspection. 
(a)  Upon completion of any installation of electrical wiring and equipment which has been made under permit, it shall be the duty of the person making the installation to notify the Electrical Inspector, who shall inspect the installation within twenty-four (24) hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, of the time such notice is given or as soon thereafter as practicable. In the case of Class B licenses, the inspection may be made monthly. 
(b)  Where the Electrical Inspector finds the installation to be in conformity with the provisions of this Chapter, he shall issue to the person making the installation a certificate of approval, with a duplicate copy for delivery to the owner, authorizing the use of the installation and connection to the supply of electricity. He shall send written notice of such authorization to the agency supplying the electric service. 
(c)  When a certificate of approval is issued authorizing the connection and use of a temporary installation, such certificates shall be issued to expire at a time to be stated therein. The certificates shall be revocable by the Electrical Inspector for cause. 
(d)  When any electrical equipment is to be hidden from view by the permanent placement of parts of the building, the person installing the equipment shall notify the Electrical Inspector. Such equipment shall not be concealed until it has been inspected and approved by the Electrical Inspector; provided, that on large installations where the concealment of equipment proceeds continuously, the person installing the electrical equipment shall give the Electrical Inspector due notice. Inspections shall be made periodically during the progress of the work. 
(e)  If, upon inspection, the installation is not found to be fully in conformity with the provisions of this Chapter, the Electrical Inspector shall at once forward to the person making the installation notice to make the necessary correction immediately and call for reinspection. 
(Code 1962, § 11-40)

ARTICLE 1. - FIRE CODE 

Sec. 9-1. - Definition. 
    As used in this chapter, the Indiana Fire Code, hereinafter referred to as the IFC means the fire prevention code of the City. 
(Ord. No. 6230-77, § 1; Ord. No. 7692-86, § 1; Ord. No. 8925-98, 7-27-98) 
Sec. 9-2. - Indiana Fire Code adopted by reference. 
    The fire code edition, adopted by reference and incorporated into Chapter 6, Section 5 of the South Bend Municipal Code, pursuant to IC 22-13-2-3(B), International Code Council (ICC), together with any and all amendments and supplements thereto is made a part of this chapter with the same force and effect as though set out in full herein as the official fire prevention code of the City of South Bend, Indiana, except for such changes, additions or deletions as are specified in this chapter. Copies of such fire code with such amendments and supplements are on file and open for public inspection in the offices of the Fire Department, Department of Code Enforcement, and city clerk's office of the City of South Bend, Indiana. 
(Ord. No. 6230-77, § 1; Ord. No. 7692-86, § 2; Ord. No. 8239-92, § 1; Ord. No. 8925-98, 7-27-98; Ord. No. 9575-05, § I)

ARTICLE 2. - SMOKE DETECTOR REGULATIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 7956-89, adopted Jan. 9, 1989, amended Ch. 9, Art. 2 in its entirety to read as set out in §§ 9-9-9-17. Inasmuch as these already existed as §§ 9-16 and 9-17, the editor has renumbered §§ 9-16 and 9-17, as enacted by Ord. No. 7956-89, as §§ 9-15.1 and 9-15-2. Prior to amendment, Art. 2 contained §§ 9-9-9-15, which pertained to smoke detectors in multiple-dwelling and rental dwelling units and derived from Ord. No. 6767-80, § 1, adopted April 14, 1980; Ord. No. 6879-81, § 1, adopted Jan. 12, 1981; and 7692-86, § 6, adopted Oct. 13, 1986. 

Sec. 9-9. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as "Smoke Detector Regulations." 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-10. - Intent and purposes. 
    The Common Council hereby declares that to require installation of smoke detection equipment and to require its proper maintenance in all: 
(1)  Multiple-dwelling units; 
(2)  All family dwelling units operated as rental property; and 
(3)  Family dwelling units constructed or remodeled after the effective date of this article and required to have a permit pursuant to section 6-24 of this Code, will benefit the public health, safety and welfare of the community. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-11. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article: 
(1)  Alarm signal means an audible signal of at least eighty-five (85) decibels at ten (10) feet, and capable of persisting at such level for at least four (4) minutes. 
(2)  Corridor means a hallway or other area on each floor providing access to individual dwelling areas within a multiple-dwelling unit. 
(3)  Family dwelling unit means any structure, area, room or combination of rooms not considered a multiple dwelling unit, as defined herein, in which a family or individual(s) lives. This is meant to cover living areas only and not common usage areas such as corridors. 
(4)  Labeled, when pertaining to equipment or materials, means an attached label, symbol or other identifying mark acceptable to the South Bend Fire Department and the Building Department of the City of South Bend. 
(5)  Listed, when pertaining to equipment or materials, means inclusion on a list published by an organization acceptable to the South Bend Fire Department and the Building Department of the City of South Bend indicating that a product meets appropriate standards or has been tested and found suitable for use in a specified manner. 
(6)  Multiple-dwelling units shall include the following classifications: 
(a)  Apartment house, which shall be defined as set forth in section 21-1(a)(3) of this Code. 
(b)  Boardinghouse, which shall be defined as set forth in section 21-11.02 of this Code. 
(c)  Hotel, motel, lodging house or rooming house, which shall be defined as set forth in section 11-15(1) of this Code. 
(7)  NFPA74 means standard 74 of the National Fire Protection Association, which is located in Batterymarch Park, Quincy, Maryland, 02269. 
(8)  Rental agent means any person, partnership or corporation, who rents, subleases, lets or otherwise grants for consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. This term shall not be construed to mean a real estate agent who is employed for the sole purpose of selling residential units. 
(9)  Sleeping area means the area or areas of the multiple-dwelling unit or family dwelling unit in which the bedrooms (or areas used for sleeping purposes) separated by other use areas, such as kitchens or living rooms, (but not bathrooms) are located. 
(10)  Shall indicates a mandatory requirement. 
(11)  Smoke detector means a device which detects visible or invisible particles or combustion as listed by Underwriters' Laboratory, Inc., and which conform to the Uniform Building Code Standard No. 43-61, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-12. - Basic requirements. 
(a)  All multiple-dwelling units and all family dwelling units operated as rental property within the corporate limits of the City of South Bend, Indiana, shall be equipped with the minimum number of functional, properly located, labeled and listed, smoke detector(s), or their equivalent or better, as described in NFPA74. 
(b)  All family dwelling units constructed or remodeled after the effective date of this article which require a permit(s) pursuant to section 6-24 of this Code and which are within the corporate limits of the City of South Bend, Indiana, shall be equipped with the minimum number of functional, properly located, labeled and listed, smoke detector(s) or their equivalent or better, as described in NFPA74. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-13. - Installation; location. 
(a)  Smoke detectors shall be installed and located as follows: 
(1)  All smoke detectors shall meet the minimum number requirements as set forth herein and shall be installed according to the manufacturer's instructions. 
(2)  In apartment houses and existing hotels and motels, the smoke detector shall be mounted on the ceiling or wall every thirty (30) feet, at the point centrally located in the corridor, but in no event more than fifteen (15) feet from the end of such corridor, and in the immediate vicinity of, but in no event more than fifteen (15) feet from all sleeping areas. 
(3)  In boardinghouses, lodging houses, rooming houses and new construction hotels and motels, or those hotels or motels in which corridors or sleeping rooms are remodeled after the effective date of this article, the smoke detectors shall be centrally located on the ceiling of each sleeping area and every thirty (30) feet along each corridor, but in no event more than fifteen (15) feet from the end of such corridor. 
(4)  In all family dwelling units, the smoke detectors shall be installed and located outside of the bedrooms but in the immediate vicinity of the sleeping areas within fifteen (15) feet of all rooms used as sleeping areas. 
(b)  The smoke detector shall be installed on or near the ceiling, not less than six (6) inches from any wall, or on a wall not less than six (6) inches, nor more than twelve (12) inches from the ceiling. No smoke detector shall be recessed into the ceiling. Smoke detector installation shall be subject to the approval of the South Bend Fire Department and the Building Department of the City of South Bend, when installed in conjunction with the permit requirements of Section 6-24 of this Code. 
(c)  Smoke detectors may be A.C.-powered only if they are directly attached to a junction box not controlled by any switch other than the main power supply. The installation of A.C.-powered smoke detectors shall comply with the electrical code adopted by the Building Department of the City of South Bend. 
(d)  All smoke detectors shall be accessible for servicing and testing. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-14. - Maintenance; testing. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or remove any smoke detector, except when it is necessary for maintenance or inspection purposes. Any smoke detector removed for repair or replacement shall be reinstalled or replaced so that it is operable and in place during normal sleeping hours. 
(b)  Multiple-dwelling units and family dwelling units operated as rental property. Each smoke detector in each multiple-dwelling unit and in each family dwelling unit operated as rental property may be tested in accordance with manufacturer's recommendation, but shall be tested at not more than six (6) month intervals and maintained as necessary to ensure it is in operable condition. At any change of tenancy, smoke detectors shall be tested and be in operable condition before the unit is reoccupied. 
(c)  Family dwelling units. Each smoke detector in each family dwelling unit may be tested in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations, but shall be tested at not more than six (6) month intervals and maintained as necessary, to ensure it is in operable condition. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-15. - Duty of property owner, manager or rental agent. 
    Every owner, or manager or rental agent of such owner, of any multiple-dwelling unit or family dwelling unit shall be responsible for the installation and maintenance of required smoke detectors. It is the responsibility of the tenant to maintain in good working order all such smoke detectors provided by the owner, including replacement of batteries, as needed, in any battery powered smoke detector provided by the owner. The complete maintenance of any smoke detector connected to the building wiring system shall be the responsibility of the owner, manager or agent of the property. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-15.1. - Enforcement; inspection prerequisite to issuance of business license; limited inspections of family dwelling units. 
(a)  The Building Department of the City of South Bend with the assistance of the South Bend Fire Department shall be, and hereby is, charged with the duty of enforcing the terms of this article. 
(b)  Before a license can be issued for the operation of any hotel, motel, rooming house or lodging house, pursuant to this Code, said buildings shall be inspected to ensure that all smoke detectors required by this article are in place and operable. 
(c)  When a family dwelling unit is remodeled or constructed after the effective date of this article and requires a permit pursuant to Section 6-24 of this Code, inspections shall include compliance with the smoke detector regulations included herein. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-15.2. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article, or who shall fail to comply with the lawful order issued by the South Bend Fire Department and/or the Building Department of the City of South Bend, for each such violation or failure shall be fined in the amount of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation. 
(b)  Each day such violation is permitted to continue may be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 7956-89, § 1)

ARTICLE 3. - AMBULANCE/MEDICAL USER FEE AND DEDICATED FUND 

Sec. 9-16. - Ambulance/medical user fee-Established. 
(a)  The following user fee schedule shall be charged for all ambulance/medical services provided by the City through its paramedic branch of the Fire Department: 
  Type of Service Provided Resident Nonresident (1) Basic Life Support (BLS Nonemergency) $322.19 $428.51 (2) Basic Life Support-(BLS Emergency) 515.49 685.60 (3) Advanced Life Support-(ALS Nonemergency) 386.63 514.2 (4) Advanced Life Support-Emergency (ALS-1 Emergency) 612.15 814.16 (5) Advanced Life Support-(ALS-2 Emergency) 886.01 1,178.39 (6) Mileage, Basic (Within City Limits) (per patient miles, minimum one (1) mile) 12.66 12.66 (7) Mileage, Rural (per patient miles, minimum one (1) mile) 19.16 19.16 (8) Nontransport Medical Calls 150.00 200.00 (9) Specialized Care (AO 434) 1,047.09 1,392.66  
(b)  The above fees shall be charged per patient run occurrence; however, when ambulance/medical services are provided for a patient using a private ambulance, the mileage fee shall not be charged; and further provided that when more than two (2) members of an immediate family residing at the same address are transported per incident, the basic fee, mileage fee, and emergency fee shall only be billed for two (2) persons. 
(c)  Non-resident : Is defined as a person whose primary residence at the time of the service is outside the corporate boundaries of the City of South Bend, Indiana. 
(d)  Basic Life Support (BLS): Means transportation by ground ambulance vehicle and medically necessary supplies and services, plus the provision of BLS ambulance services. The ambulance must be staffed by an individual who is qualified in accordance with State and local laws as an Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) 1 . 
(e)  Advanced Life Support, Level 1 (ALS1) : Means transportation by ground ambulance vehicles, medically necessary supplies and services and either an ALS assessment by ALS personnel or the provision of at least one ALS intervention. 
(f)  Advance Life Support, Level 2 (ALS2) : Means either transportation by ground ambulance vehicle, medically necessary supplies and services, and the administration of at least three (3) medications by intravenous pus/bolus or by continuous infusion excluding crystalloid, hypotonic, isotonic, and hypertonic solutions (Dextrose, Normal Saline, Ringer's Lactate); or transportation, medically necessary supplies and services, and the provision of at least one (1) of the following: 
(1)  Manual defibrillation/cardioversion 
(2)  Endotracheal intubation 
(3)  Central venous line 
(4)  Cardiac pacing 
(5)  Chest decompression 
(6)  Surgical airway 
(7)  Intraosseous line 
(g)  Non-Transport Medical Calls: Means a response to a medical emergency call by ambulance vehicle and the administration of ALS skills upon or medication given to a patient who then refuses transport to the hospital. 
(h)  Mileage, Rural, shall apply to vehicle runs made to areas in zones or zip codes designated as rural by Medicare and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services in its Medicare regulations. 
(i)  The above fees shall take effect on August 1, 2016. 
(j)  Hereafter, and in the event Medicare or other federal or State health care regulations require or allow an adjustment to ambulance/ medical user fees, the South Bend Fire Chief is authorized to and may amend once annually the user fees set out in subpart (a) of this section by the same percentage as the Medicare Fee Schedule rates for such services have been adjusted. This adjustment shall be effective on the calendar date immediately following the date on which written notice of said fee rate adjustment is filed in the office of the City Clerk. At the time such notice is filed, a copy of the new rates shall be made available in paper form for public viewing in the South Bend Central Fire Station, and such new rates shall also be published promptly on the City's web site. 
(Ord. No. 6897-81, § 1; Ord. No. 7414-84, § 1; Ord. No. 7578-85, § 1; Ord. No. 8009-89, § 1; Ord. No. 8269-92, § 1; Ord. No. 8860-97, § I; Ord. No. 9340-02, § 1; Ord. No. 9887-08, § I, 12-8-08; Ord. No. 10204-12, § I, 11-26-12; Ord. No. 10321-14, § I, 8-25-14; Ord. No. 10368-15, § I, 7-13-15; Ord. No. 10444-16 , § I, 6-27-16) 
1  ALS1, ALS2 and BLS definitions track the language codified in Title 42 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Chapter IV, §414.605 entitled "Fee Schedule for Ambulance Services". 
Sec. 9-17. - EMS Operating Enterprise Fund #288. 
(a)  The revenues generated by the ambulance/medical use fees set forth in Section 9-16 shall be deposited into EMS Operating Enterprise Fund #288. 
(b)  EMS Operating Enterprise Fund #288 shall operate as an enterprise fund for the benefit of the South Bend Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 6897-81, § 1; Ord. No. 7578-85, § 2; Ord. No. 8009-89, § 2; Ord. No. 8269-92, § 2; Ord. No. 8710-96, § I; Ord. No. 9887-08, § I, 12-8-08; Ord. No. 10204-12, § II, 11-26-12; Ord. No. 10339-14, § I, 11-24-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10339-14, § I, adopted Nov. 24, 2014, amended § 9-17 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Dedication of ambulance/medical user fee revenues to the EMS/Fire Department Capital Fund #288, quarterly transfers; establishing when repayment of monies is required" to "EMS Operating Enterprise Fund #288," as set out herein. 
Sec. 9-17.1 - EMS Capital Enterprise Fund #287. 
(a)  The EMS Capital Enterprise Fund #287 is created to be a companion fund to Fund #288 for the benefit of the South Bend Fire Department. 
(b)  The EMS Capital Enterprise Fund #287 shall track capital expenditures of the South Bend Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 10339-14, § II, 11-24-14) 
Sec. 9-18. - Review of user fees by Common Council following Annual Report from the South Bend Fire Department. 
(a)  The South Bend Fire Department shall prepare a report and file the same with the office of The City Clerk on or before June 1 st of each year. Said report shall summarize ambulance/medical service runs for the entire preceding fiscal year by identifying the number and type of each run; amount billed; amount collected; amount in collection; number of lawsuits filed; and recommendations with regard to fee amounts. Any recommended fee adjustments shall include reasons for the requested adjustments. 
(b)  The Common Council shall review the report filed annually by the South Bend Fire Department. The Council's Personnel and Finance Committee and/or the Council's Health and Public Safety Committee shall make a formal recommendation to the Common Council following a public hearing. Data contained in the annual report and testimony provided at the committee's hearing shall be used in determining fair and equitable user fees. 
(Ord. No. 6897-81, § 1; Ord. No. 9887-08, § I, 12-8-08; Ord. No. 10321-14, § II, 8-25-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10321-14, § II, adopted Aug. 25, 2014, amended § 9-18 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Annual review of user fees by Common Council following September 1 report from the South Bend Fire Department" to "Review of User Fees by Common Council following Annual Report from the South Bend Fire Department," as set out herein. 
ARTICLE 4. - LEAF BURNING AND AIR POLLUTION CONTROL[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Air pollution control, § 13-76 et seq. 

Sec. 9-19. - Intent and purposes of article. 
    The Common Council believes that reasonable regulations should be enacted to minimize air pollution caused by burning within our City. 
(Ord. No. 7895-88, § 1; Ord. No. 8023-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-20. - Types of burning prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall start, kindle, cause, allow or maintain any form of leaf burning or rubbish or trash burning on private or public property, except as specifically authorized by this Code. 
(b)  No person shall burn or cause to be burned, any leaves, grass, tree limbs, branches, paper, rubbish or trash, upon any street, alley or sidewalk within the City. 
(Ord. No. 7895-88, § 1; Ord. No. 8023-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-21. - Reserved.[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Former § 9-21, permitting leaf burning on alternate days, was deleted by § 1 of Ord. No. 8023-89, adopted Oct. 9, 1989. Such deleted provisions derived from Ord. No. 7895-88, § 1. 

Sec. 9-22. - Operation "ReLEAF." 
(a)  Beginning in the fall 1989 leaf pick-up season, the City shall institute a leaf pick-up program which will encompass using leaf vacuums as the primary collection tool. 
(b)  In conjunction with the leaf vacuums, all trash haulers shall continue to pick-up bagged leaves, as a condition of their license issued by the City. 
(c)  The City shall develop a program so that biodegradable bags can be purchased by citizens from the City. 
(d)  Public education programs shall be developed by the City in conjunction with the leaf burning task force. 
(e)  The service charge per customer for this program shall be ninety-nine cents ($0.99) per month effective January 1, 2006. Until then previously established rates shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 7895-88, § 1; Ord. No. 8023-89, § 1; Ord. No. 9641-05, § I, 11-18-05) 
Sec. 9-23. - Leaf burning task force. 
(a)  The leaf burning task force of not more than fifteen (15) persons with eight (8) individuals being appointed by the Common Council and seven (7) individuals being appointed by the Mayor, each for two (2) year terms, shall meet on or before April 1, 1990, to review the results of the 1989 fall leaf burning season. 
(b)  The leaf burning task force shall provide a written report to the Common Council and the Mayor on or before June 1, 1990, with regard to further recommendations which should be studied by the City. The report shall also detail a summary of all current and proposed public education programs. 
(c)  The leaf burning task force shall study equipment needs and costs thereof, personnel needs, and all related issues in their written report. 
(Ord. No. 7895-88, § 1; Ord. No. 8023-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-24. - Citations. 
(a)  Any person found in violation of this article shall be subject to the following procedures. The Department of Code Enforcement, Fire Department, or Police Department personnel shall: 
(1)  Issue a citation to the violator imposing a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine for each violation. 
(b)  Each subsequent starting, kindling, causing, or allowing of a new fire after a citation has been issued, shall be considered a separate offense for which a citation may be issued. 
(c)  The citation issued under this article shall contain the date, time, name and address of the violator, the code section violated, the nature of the violation, location of the violation, the name of the officer or inspector issuing the citation and instructions as to the disposition of the citation. 
(d)  In such instances where a leaf burning fire results in damage and is determined to be caused by negligence or the wilful disregard or violation of any of the provisions of this article, a fine equal to the cost expended by the City to send fire suppression personnel and equipment to the location shall be assessed with said fine not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(e)  In the case of indigency of the defendant, the provisions of Section 1-24 of this Code shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 7895-88, § 1; Ord. No. 8023-89, § 1) 
Sec. 9-25. - Reserved.[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Former § 9-25, pertaining to a sunset provision, was deleted by § 1 of Ord. No. 8023-89, adopted Oct. 9, 1989. The deleted provisions derived from Ord. No. 7980-89, § 1. 

ARTICLE 5. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS AND TACTICAL RESCUE TEAM[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10275-13, § I, adopted Dec. 9, 2013, amended Art. 5 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. 5, §§ 9-26 and 9-27, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 8921-98, § I, adopted July 13, 1998. 

Sec. 9-26. - Definitions and hazardous materials team user fees and costs established. 
(a)  Definitions: As used in this Article, the following definitions apply: 
(1)  Hazardous materials shall have the definition set forth in IC 13-11-2-96, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(2)  Hazardous materials emergency shall have the definition set forth in IC 13-11-2-97, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  Hazardous substance shall have the definition set forth in IC 13-11-2-98, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(4)  Hazardous waste shall have the definition set forth in IC 13-11-2-99, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(5)  Responsible party shall have the definition set forth in IC 13-11-2-191, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(6)  Responsible person shall have the definition set forth in IC 13-11-2-192, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(b)  Hazardous Materials Team User Fees: The following user fee schedule shall be charged by the South Bend Fire Department to the responsible party for all hazardous materials emergencies responses by the department's Hazardous Materials Team in taking emergency action at an address or near the scene of a hazardous materials emergency involving hazardous materials, hazardous substances, and/or hazardous waste: 
(1)  Basic fee (For up to a Maximum four (4) hours) ..... $3,000.00 
(2)  Additional per hour charge (after four (4) hours) ..... $ 825.00 
(3)  Computation of the time set for above shall include any fraction of an hour and shall run from the time of dispatch to the time the Hazardous Materials Team reports back in service. 
Emergency responses and cleanup for spills of gasoline, diesel fuel, waste oil or other engine fluids at gasoline stations shall be charged to the party requesting a response. Any petroleum spills involving a motor carrier where there is the potential to create fire, traffic and/or pollution threat(s) on a street, road or highway, the motor carrier shall be charged. 
(c)  Charges for Replacement Costs and Overtime: In addition to the above, the Fire Department shall charge for the replacement costs for disposable materials and supplies acquired, consumed and expended specifically for the purpose of the response, as well as replacement costs for equipment owned by the Fire Department that is contaminated or otherwise damaged beyond reuse or repair during the response. This charge shall be made regardless of the location of the incident. In the event that the Fire Department is required to backfill employees resulting in overtime after the initial four (4) hour period, those expenses shall be calculated and charged to the responsible party. 
(d)  Mileage Fees for Out of City Responses: Mileage fees shall be charged for each vehicle used by the South Bend Fire Department's Hazardous Materials Team which is involved in responding at an address or near the scene of a hazardous materials emergency involving hazardous materials, hazardous substances, and/or hazardous waste which is located outside of the City of South Bend corporate limits. Such mileage fees shall be twelve dollars and eighty-four cents ($12.84) per mile from the point of dispatch for the round trip, with a minimum of one (1) mile being charged. 
(e)  Liability of Payment of User Fees and Costs: The above fees and costs shall be charged on a per run occurrence to the responsible party and/or person. The owner of the property at the address responded to, and if known, the person or persons whose actions in whole or in part made the emergency receiver response necessary shall be jointly and severally liable for the fees. 
(Ord. No. 10275-13, § I, 12-9-13) 
Sec. 9-27. - Definitions, standards and tactical rescue team user fees and costs established. 
(a)  Services; Standards and Definitions: 
(1)  The South Bend Fire Department's Tactical Rescue Team (TRT) is specially trained to provide services in rope rescue; vehicle and machinery search and rescue; trench and excavation search and rescue; and structural collapse. 
(2)  Technical rescues are governed by departmental standards as well as standards imposed by: 
NFPA 1670: Operations and Training for Technical Search and Rescue Incidents 1 
NFPA 1006: Rescue Technician Professional Qualifications 
(3)  Definitions set forth in the above-referenced NFPA standards shall govern this Article, copies of which are on file in the Administrative Offices of the Central Fire Station. 
(b)  Tactical Rescue Team User Fees: The following user fee schedule shall be charged by the South Bend Fire Department to the responsible party for all tactical rescue responses provided by the department's Tactical Rescue Team (TRT): 
(1)  Basic fee (For up to a Maximum four (4) hours) ..... $3,000.00 
(2)  Additional per hour charge (after four (4) hours) ..... $825.00 
(3)  Computation of the time set for above shall include any fraction of an hour and shall run from the time of dispatch to the time the Technical Response Team reports back in service. 
(c)  Charges for Replacement Costs and Overtime: In addition to the above, the Fire Department shall charge for the replacement costs for disposable materials and supplies acquired, consumed, and expended specifically for the purpose of the response as well as replacement costs for equipment owned by the Fire Department that is contaminated or otherwise damaged beyond reuse or repair during the response. This charge shall be made regardless of the location of the incident. In the event that the Fire Department is required to backfill employees resulting in overtime after the initial four (4) hour period, those expenses shall be calculated and charged to the responsible party. 
(d)  Mileage Fees for Out of City Responses: Mileage fees shall be charged for each vehicle used by the South Bend Fire Department's Tactical Rescue Team which is involved in responding at an address or near the scene of a tactical rescue emergency which is located outside of the City of South Bend corporate limits. Such mileage fees shall be twelve dollars and eighty-four cents ($12.84) per mile from the point of dispatch for the round trip, with a minimum of one (1) mile being charged. 
(e)  Liability of Payment of User Fees and Costs: The above fees shall be charged on a per run occurrence to the responsible party, the beneficiary of the services, the owner of the property, and if known, the person or persons whose actions in whole or in part made the emergency receiver response necessary shall be jointly and severally liable for the fees. 
(Ord. No. 10275-13, § I, 12-9-13) 
1 The National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) was established in 1896. It provides codes and standards, research, training and education designed to minimize the risks and effects of fire and develops technical codes and standards. 
Sec. 9-28. - Hazardous materials team user fees and tactical rescue team user fees and related charges collected to be deposited into the Hazmat Fund #289; collection for recovery including attorney fees; quarterly reports from the fire department. 
(a)  All monies collected under this Article shall be deposited into the Hazmat Fund, Fund #289. 
(b)  Monies collected shall be used for the purchase of needed supplies and equipment used in providing hazardous materials and tactical rescue emergency assistance and training. 
(c)  The responsible party billed for services under this Article may elect to reimburse the Fire Department by providing replacement materials that are of equal or greater value than those expended by the Fire Department in responding to the emergency. 
(d)  The fire department may pursue action for reimbursement under IC 36-8-12.2-10 to recover all costs of the action, including attorney's fees. 
(e)  Quarterly reports summarizing the number of runs by the Hazardous Materials Team and the Tactical Rescue Team, total amount billed, total amount collected, and information related to the regulations in this Article shall be filed by the South Bend Fire Department at the beginning of each calendar quarter with the Office of the City Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 10275-13, § I, 12-9-13) 
Sec. 9-29. - Penalties for failure to pay. 
(a)  Pursuant to IC 36-8-12.2-11, a responsible party shall be subject to a penalty for failure to pay the full amount of a charge under this Article within sixty (60) days after the issuance of the bill for payment by the Fire Department. 
(b)  Ten percent (10%) of the amount of the charge that remains unpaid on the due date shall be the penalty amount. 
(Ord. No. 10275-13, § I, 12-9-13) 
Sec. 9-30. - Limited fee exemptions for emergencies involving local units of government governed by mutual aid agreement. 
(a)  Definitions . As used in this article, the following definitions apply: 
(1)  Emergency shall mean any occurrence, or threat thereof, whether natural or caused by man, in war or in peace, which results or may result in substantial injury or harm to the populations, substantial damage to or loss of property, or substantial harm to the environment and is beyond the capacity of an individual jurisdiction to effectively control. 
(2)  Mutual Aid shall mean a prearranged written agreement and plan whereby assistance is requested and provided between two (2) or more jurisdictions during a designated emergency under terms of the District 2 Mutual Aid Inter-Local Government Agreement. 
(b)  The user fees for the South Bend Fire Department's Hazardous Materials Team set forth in Section 9-26 and the user fees for the South Bend Fire Department's Tactical Rescue Team (TRT) set forth in Section 9-27 of the article shall not be charged for mutual aid services provided by such teams to a local unit of government who is governed by the District 2 Mutual Aid Inter-Local Government Agreement during an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 10305-14, § I, 4-28-14) 
Secs. 9-31-9-33. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 10 - FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of local health departments, IC 16-20-1-1 et seq.; city health department, IC 16-20-4-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE 1. - FOOD VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions.[2] 
    As used in this article: 
(1)  Adulterated, misbranded have the same meanings as provided in the "Indiana Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act" in "IC 16-1-28-1 et seq. and IC 16-1-29-1 et seq. 
(2)  Commissary means commissary, catering establishment, restaurant or any other place in which food, beverage, ingredients, containers or supplies are kept, handled, prepared, stored and directly from which vending machines are serviced. 
(3)  Employee means any operator or any person employed by him who handles food to be dispensed through vending machines or who comes into contact with food contact surfaces of containers, equipment, utensils or packaging materials used in connection with vending machine operation or who otherwise services or maintains one (1) or more machines. 
(4)  Food means any raw, cooked or processed edible substances, beverage or ingredient used or intended for use in whole or in part for human consumption; food also means all articles used for food, drink, confectionery or condiment whether simple, mixed or compound, and all substances or ingredients used in the preparation thereof. 
(5)  Health officer means the official having the power and jurisdiction to enforce public health laws and regulations within the City. 
(6)  Hot liquid food means any liquid food or beverage, the temperature of which at the time of service to the consumer is at least one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(7)  Machine location means any room, enclosure, space or area where one (1) or more vending machines are installed and operated. 
(8)  Operator means any person who, by contract, agreement or ownership, is responsible for furnishing, installing, servicing, operating or maintaining one (1) or more vending machines. 
(9)  Product contact surface means any surface of a vending machine, appurtenance or container which comes into direct contact with any food. 
(10)  Readily perishable food means any food, beverage or ingredient consisting in whole or in part of milk, milk products, eggs, fish, poultry or other food capable of supporting rapid and progressive growth of microorganisms which can cause food infections or food intoxication; provided, products in hermatically sealed containers processed by heat or other methods approved by the Health Officer to prevent spoilage and dehydrated, dry or powdered products so low in moisture content as to preclude development of microorganisms are excluded from the terms of this definition. 
(11)  Single service article means any utensil, container, implement or wrapper intended for use only once in the preparation, storage, display, service or consumption of any food or beverage. 
(12)  Vending machine means any self-service device offered for public use, which, upon insertion of a coin, coins or tokens or by other similar means, dispenses unit servings of food or beverage, either in bulk or in package, without the necessity of replenishing the device between each vending operation; provided, that machines dispensing only bottled or canned soft drinks, prepackaged nonperishable confections and similar items or ball gum, nuts and panned candies shall not be considered vending machines under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Definitions, IC 16-18-2-1 et seq.; administrative rules IC 4-22-2-3 et seq.; authority for rules, IC 16-42-5-5. 

Sec. 10-2. - Vending machine license required. 
(a)  No person shall operate one (1) or more vending machines in the City who does not possess a valid license for the operation of such vending machine or vending machines. 
(b)  The license shall be for a term of one (1) year beginning January 1 and expiring December 31 of the same year. It shall be renewed annually. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-2) 
Sec. 10-3. - Vending machine license; exception. 
    No person holding a valid City restaurant permit and license shall be required to obtain a permit or pay a license fee required in this article for the operation of food or beverage vending machines if such vending machines are operated by such person on the licensed restaurant premises. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-3) 
Sec. 10-4. - Vending machine license; fees. 
(a)  An operator's license shall be provided by the Controller if there is presented at his office a valid permit from the Health Officer, together with the proper fee of forty dollars ($40.00) per location of machine(s). 
(b)  If the application for a vending operator's license is made on or after July 1, the operator license fee shall be one-half (1/2) the fee prescribed in the appropriate licensing category above. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-4.; Ord. No. 9093-00, § XXV) 
Sec. 10-5. - Vending machine license; transferability. 
    Any license issued by the Controller pursuant to this article shall be nonassignable and nontransferable. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - Operator's permit required; exception. 
(a)  No person shall operate one or more vending machines in the City who does not possess a valid operator's permit from the Health Officer. Only persons who comply with the provisions of this article shall be entitled to receive and retain such a permit. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall apply to and a permit required by Subsection (a) shall be obtained for vending machines operated by fraternal organizations, service clubs and religious, educational or charitable institutions. No license shall be required and no fee shall be paid for vending machines operated by fraternal organizations, services clubs and religious, educational or charitable institutions. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-6) 
Sec. 10-7. - Operator's permit; application; contents. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate one or more vending machines in the City shall make application in writing to the Health Officer. 
(b)  The application shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's full name, residence and post office address and whether such applicant is an individual, firm or corporation, and if any partnership exists, the names of the partners, together with their addresses shall be included. 
(2)  The location of the commissary or commissaries and other establishments where supplies are kept and where vending machines are repaired or renovated. 
(3)  The identity and form of the products to be dispensed through vending machines and the number of each such type of vending machine in operation by the applicant in the City. 
(4)  The location of the commissary or commissaries or other establishment where foods within the purview of this article are prepared for direct distribution or dispensing through vending machines. 
(5)  The signature of the applicant. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-7) 
Sec. 10-8. - Operator's permit; inspection; issuance; transferability. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the application, the Health Officer shall make an inspection of the commissary, servicing and transport facilities and representative machines and machine locations to determine compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  A numbered operator's permit shall be issued to the applicant by the Health Officer after compliance by the operator with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The permit shall not be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-8) 
Sec. 10-9. - Operator's permit; number display. 
    The operator's permit number, of a size and style approved by the Health Officer, shall be visibly displayed at each vending machine location by him. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-9) 
Sec. 10-10. - Operator's permit; suspension; revocation. 
    After an opportunity for a hearing, an operator's permit may be temporarily suspended by the Health Officer upon violation by the permit holder of any of the provisions of this article or may be revoked upon serious or repeated violation of such provisions. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-10) 
Sec. 10-11. - Operator's permit; reinstatement. 
    Any operator whose permit has been suspended may at any time make application for the reinstatement of the permit. Within ten (10) days after the receipt of a written application, the Health Officer shall make a reinspection. If the applicant is again complying with the terms of this article the permit shall be reinstated. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-11) 
Sec. 10-12. - Listing of machines required. 
    In order to hold and retain an operator's permit, the operator shall maintain within the City a list of all vending machines operated by him and their location and of all commissaries or other establishments from which his machines are serviced. This information shall be available to the Health Officer upon request. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-12) 
Sec. 10-13. - Change of operation; notification of Health Officer. 
    In order to hold and retain an operator's permit, the operator shall notify the Health Officer of any change in operations involving new types of vending machines or conversion of existing machines to dispense products other than those for which the permit was issued. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-13) 
Sec. 10-14. - Inspection of premises and machines; access. 
(a)  The Health Officer shall inspect the servicing, maintenance and operation of representative vending machines dispensing readily perishable foods and commissaries at least once every six (6) months. Vending machines dispensing other than readily perishable foods may be inspected by the Health Officer as often as he deems necessary. 
(b)  The Health Officer, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter at any reasonable time upon any private or public property within the City where vending machines or commissaries are operated or from which such machines are serviced for the purpose of determining compliance with the provisions of this article. The operator shall make provisions for the Health Officer to have access, either in company with an employee or otherwise, to the interior of all vending machines operated by him. [3] 
(Code 1962, § 15A-14) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Local health officers, IC 16-42-5-24. 

Sec. 10-15. - Sale of adulterated or misbranded food prohibited. 
    No person shall sell, offer or expose for sale, through vending machines or to have in possession with intent to sell therefrom any food, beverage or ingredient which is adulterated or misbranded. 
(Code 1962, § 15-15) 
Sec. 10-16. - Examination and condemnation of food; exception. 
(a)  Samples of food may be taken and examined by the Health Officer as often as may be necessary to determine freedom from adulteration or misbranding. The Health Officer may, on written notice to the operator, impound and forbid the sale of any food which is adulterated or misbranded or which he has probable cause to believe to be adulterated or misbranded. 
(b)  After the operator has been given an opportunity for a hearing, the Health Officer may cause to be removed or destroyed any food which is adulterated or misbranded. In the case of misbranding which can be corrected by proper labeling, such food may be released to the operator for correct labeling under the supervision of the Health Officer. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-16) 
Sec. 10-17. - Sanitary requirements; State regulations. 
    All vending machines, machine locations and commissaries shall comply with the applicable minimum sanitation requirements specified by the State Board of Health, as provided in its Regulation HFD No. 21, as effective July 29, 1958, and all changes or amendments. The regulation and changes and amendments are by reference incorporated herein and made part hereof. Two (2) copies of the regulation, changes and amendments are on file in the office of the Clerk for public inspection. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-17) 
Sec. 10-18. - Sanitation; equipment and utensils; responsibility. 
(a)  In vending machine locations at which the operator or the location management provide supplemental food service equipment such as can openers, ovens, condiment dispensers, utensils and similar appurtenances to vending operation for the use of vending operation for the use of vending customers, the supplemental equipment and utensils shall be protected from contamination, constructed of approved materials, fabricated so as to be easily cleanable and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the ownership of the supplemental equipment and utensils, the licensed vending machine operator whose machines are in operation at such location shall be held responsible by the Health Officer for the condition and maintenance of such supplemental equipment and utensils. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-18) 
Sec. 10-19. - Notice of violation; hearing. 
(a)  Whenever the Health Officer discovers a violation of any provision of this article, he shall notify the operator. 
(b)  The notice shall: 
(1)  Describe the condition found; 
(2)  Provide a specific and reasonable period of time for the correction of the condition; and 
(3)  State that an opportunity for a hearing on inspection findings will be provided, if a written request for such hearing is filed with the Health Officer within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-19) 
Sec. 10-20. - Sanitation; emergency procedure; reinstatement. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, whenever the Health Officer finds grossly insanitary or other conditions involving the operation of any vending machine or commissary which, in his opinion, involves a substantial hazard to the public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue a written order to the operator citing the existence of such condition and specifying corrective action to be taken and, if deemed necessary, requiring immediate discontinuance of operation. 
(b)  The order shall be effective immediately and apply only to the vending machine, commissary or product involved. Any operator to whom such order is issued shall comply therewith but, upon petition to the Health Officer, shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. When corrective action has been taken, the operator may request and the Health Officer shall make a reinspection within twenty-four hours to determine whether operations may be resumed. 
(Code 1962, § 15A-20)

Secs. 11-2-11-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - HOTELS, MOTELS, ROOMING HOUSES OR LODGING HOUSES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Architectural barriers in relation to disabled and aged persons, § 6-19 et seq.; requirements relative to hotels and motels to accommodate handicapped and aged persons, § 6-19(C)(m). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 11-15. - Definition. 
    For purposes of this article, any person having five (5) rooms or more to rent for lodging or rooming purposes, with or without meals, for compensation shall be deemed to be operating a hotel, motel, lodging house or rooming house. 
(Code 1962, § 19-1) 
Sec. 11-16. - Compliance with sanitary and fire prevention laws.[5] 
    Any person duly licensed to operate a hotel, motel, rooming house or lodging house shall at all times comply with the sanitary and fire prevention laws and regulations of this City, this County and this State. 
(Code 1962, § 19-5) 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention code, Ch. 9. 

Sec. 11-17. - Right of entry of inspectors. 
    Inspectors of the County Health Department and representatives of the Fire Department shall have the right from time to time to make inspection tours of hotels, motels, rooming houses and lodging houses, within the City at all reasonable hours for the purpose of enforcing, when necessary, the sanitary and fire prevention laws and regulations of the City, County and State. All inspectors of the Health Department and representatives of the Fire Department shall have exhibited to them, upon demand by them, the license issued by the City authorizing the operation of the establishment. 
(Code 1962, § 19-6) 
Sec. 11-18. - Compliance with Code. 
    No person shall operate a hotel, motel, rooming house or lodging house, or occupy or let to another for occupancy, any room unit in any such establishment, except in compliance with the provisions of every applicable section of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 20-20) 
Sec. 11-19. - Applicability of article to hotels. 
    Every provision of this article which applies to rooming houses or lodging houses shall also apply to hotels and motels, except to the extent that any such provision may be found in conflict with the laws of this State or with the lawful regulations of any State board or agency. 
(Code 1962, § 20-30) 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 6998-81, enacted Nov. 9, 1981, repealed former Art. 3, Div. 2, §§ 11-20-11-27, which pertained to licenses for hotels, motels, rooming houses or lodging houses. The repealed provisions derived from §§ 19-7-19-12 of the 1962 Code and Ord. No. 6721-79, § 14. 

Secs. 11-20-11-27. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RETAIL MERCHANDISING 

Sec. 11-28. - Retail merchandising in sleeping room prohibited. 
    No person shall engage in the business of retail merchandising in any room used as a sleeping or bedroom in any hotel, rooming house or lodging house within the City. 
(Code 1962, § 19-2) 
Sec. 11-29. - Renting sleeping room for retail merchandising prohibited. 
    No hotel, rooming house or lodging house keeper shall rent or permit to be used any room commonly used as a sleeping or bedroom to any person for the purpose of engaging in the business of retail merchandising. 
(Code 1962, § 19-3) 
Sec. 11-30. - Rooms used for retail merchandising to be disinfected. 
    No hotel, rooming house or lodging house keeper within the City shall rent any room as a sleeping or bedroom after such room has been used for the purpose of conducting a retail merchandising business until the room has been thoroughly disinfected. 
(Code 1962, § 19-4) 
DIVISION 4. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 11-31. - Required plumbing facilities; exception; locations. 
(a)  At least one (1) flush closet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower, properly connected to water and sewer system approved by the Building Commissioner and in good working condition, shall be supplied for each eight (8) persons or fraction thereof residing within a hotel, motel, rooming house or lodging house, including members of the operator's family wherever they share the use of such facilities. In a hotel, motel, rooming house or lodging house where rooms are let only to males, flush urinals may be substituted for not more than one-half the required number of water closets. 
(b)  All facilities shall be located within the dwelling so as to be reasonably accessible from a common hall or passageway to all persons sharing such facilities. Every lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be supplied with hot water at all times. No such facilities shall be located in a basement, except by written approval of the Building Commissioner. 
(Code 1962, § 20-25) 
Sec. 11-32. - Supplied linens. 
    The operator of every hotel, motel, rooming house or lodging house who supplies linens shall change supplied bed linen and towels at least once a week and prior to the letting of any room to any occupant. The operator shall be responsible for the maintenance of all supplied bedding in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(Code 1962, § 20-26) 
Sec. 11-33. - Minimum area requirements. 
    Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one (1) person shall contain at least seventy (70) square feet of floor space. Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one (1) person shall contain at least forty (40) square feet of floor space for each occupant. 
(Code 1962, § 20-27) 
Sec. 11-34. - Means of egress; unobstructed. 
    Every rooming unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level, as required by the laws of the State and the City. 
(Code 1962, § 20-28) 
Sec. 11-35. - Sanitary maintenance; operator's responsibility. 
    The operator of every hotel, motel, rooming house or lodging house shall be responsible for the sanitary maintenance of all walls, floors and ceilings, and for maintenance of a sanitary condition in every other part of the rooming house. He shall be responsible for the sanitary maintenance of the entire premises where the entire structure or building is leased or occupied by the operator. 
(Code 1962, § 20-29) 
ARTICLE 4. - RESERVED[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 6886-81, adopted Jan. 26, 1981, repealed former Art. 4, §§ 11-36-11-42, which pertained to vacant structures and derived from §§ 20-31-20-36, of the 1962 Code, Ord. No. 5198-70, § I and Ord. No. 6722-79, § 11. Section 2 of Ord. No. 6885-81 adopted a new Ch. 6, Art. 10, pertaining to vacant structures, in lieu of the repealed provisions.
