    As used in this article: 
(1)  A bicycle is defined as a vehicle whose weight rests on wheels, none of which are less than sixteen (16) inches in diameter, and which utilizes direct physical human power as its major source of propulsion. A vehicle utilizing a gasoline engine or some other such device as its major source of propulsion is excluded from this definition. 
(2)  Bicyclist means every person who rides or is in actual physical control of a bicycle. 
(3)  Rental agency means any person engaged in the business of offering for rental or renting bicycles for use by the public. 
(Ord. No. 5650-74, § 1) 
Secs. 20-32-20-43.1. - Reserved.[15] 
Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Editor's note- Section 10 of Ord. No. 6998-81, enacted Nov. 9, 1981, repealed former §§ 20-32-20-43.1, which pertained to bicycle licensing. Pursuant to said repeal, the deleted sections have been reserved for future use. Said sections derived from §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 5650-74. 

Sec. 20-44. - Operation of bicycles; safety.[16] 
    Every person operating a bicycle upon any street, highway or alley in the City shall at all times operate such bicycle with due regard to his own safety and the safety of other persons lawfully upon the streets and highways of the City. He shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians at crosswalks. 
(Code 1962, § 8-14) 
Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles generally, IC 9-21-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 20-45. - Riding bicycles on sidewalks; restrictions. 
(a)  Any person may ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk within a residential district. The bicycle riders shall at all times yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and give pedestrians audible warnings by horn or bell before overtaking and passing them. 
(b)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within any business district. 
(c)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk or within a roadway where official regulatory signs are placed prohibiting such riding. 
(d)  Any person riding a bicycle on the sidewalk shall come to a complete stop and give the right-of-way to all vehicular traffic before entering any roadway. 
(Code 1962, § 8-16) 
Sec. 20-46. - Bicycles to keep to right. 
    All bicycles when driven on roadways shall keep to the right and driven as nearly as is practicable to the right-hand edge of that roadway. 
(Code 1962, § 8-22) 
Sec. 20-47. - Trick riding prohibited. 
    No person shall engage in trick riding or operate any bicycle upon the streets and highways of the City without maintaining full control of such bicycle, by keeping both hands upon the handle grips except when necessary to give the required hand signal of intention to change the course of such bicycle. 
(Code 1962, § 8-23) 
Sec. 20-48. - Parking bicycles. 
    Bicycles shall not at any time in any place be indiscriminately parked by anyone along buildings or in such a manner as to interfere with pedestrian traffic or persons getting in or out of automobiles. If, in any business or commercial district or area, or adjacent to any public building or institutions, official parking zones or spaces are designated, no person shall park bicycles in such district or areas, except in such officially designated parking zones. 
(Code 1962, § 8-24) 
Sec. 20-49. - Parked bicycles; interference; exception. 
    No person shall move or in any manner interfere with any bicycle which is properly parked as required by section 20-48. No person shall interfere or in any manner hinder any person from parking a bicycle in the manner provided in section 20-48. Members of the Police or Fire Departments may move or in proper cases prevent the parking of any bicycle in the manner herein provided when, in the judgment of such policeman or fireman, the action is necessary in order to properly safeguard persons or property. 
(Code 1962, § 8-25) 
Sec. 20-50. - Bicycles; operation in violation of law; suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Whenever any bicycle is operated in violation of any provision of this article or in violation of the State traffic laws or provisions of this Code or traffic ordinances of the City, as they relate to street traffic and insofar as the laws are applicable, the bicycle may be seized by any member of the Police Department and impounded. The bicycle, if belonging to a person under sixteen (16) years of age, shall be given up to the parent or guardian of the minor without charge after a full explanation to such parent or guardian of the reason for impounding the bicycle. 
(b)  The Mayor is empowered to suspend or revoke pursuant to the provisions of section 1-18 the license of the impounded bicycle issued under the provision of this article. A complete record of such impounding, suspension or revocation of a license shall be kept in the office of the Controller, a copy of the record to be forwarded to the Police Department. 
(c)  In the event any person under the age of sixteen (16) years while riding on a registered bicycle other than his own violates any provision of this article, the traffic ordinances of the City or State traffic laws as designated above, then the owner of such bicycle shall be held responsible for the illegal operation, and the license and registration of such bicycle shall be subject to revocation as herein provided. 
(Code 1962, § 8-26) 
ARTICLE 5. - PARKING METERS 

Sec. 20-51. - Parking meter zones. 
    The following designated areas, streets or portions of streets and such other areas, streets or portions of streets as may hereafter be included in this section by amendment hereto, shall constitute and are hereby established as parking meter zones, and all frontage in such squares, streets or avenues defining the zones shall be included therein: 
Carroll Street, from Lincolnway east to Wayne Street. 
Colfax Avenue, from Michigan Street to William Street. 
Franklin Street, from Washington Avenue to Jefferson Boulevard. 
Franklin Street, from Wayne Street to Western Avenue. 
Jefferson from William to Taylor. 
Jefferson Boulevard, from William Street to the west end of the St. Joseph River bridge. 
LaFayette from LaSalle to Marion. 
LaFayette Boulevard, from Madison Street to South Street. 
LaSalle Avenue, from William Street to the east end of the St. Joseph River bridge. 
Lincolnway East, from Jefferson Boulevard Southeast to the alley between Wayne Street and Jefferson Boulevard. 
Lincolnway East, from Washington Avenue to Columbia Street. 
Lincolnway West, from LaSalle Avenue to William Street. 
Madison Street, from LaFayette Boulevard to a point one hundred eighty (180) feet east of Michigan Street. 
Main Street, from Madison Street to Monroe Street. 
Michigan Street, from Marion Street to Garst Street. 
Monroe Street, from William Street to St. Joseph Street. 
St. Joseph Street, from LaSalle Avenue to Monroe Street. 
South Street, from Main Street to St. Joseph Street. 
Washington Avenue, from William Street to Artesian Avenue. 
Wayne Street, from William Street to Carroll Street. 
Western Avenue, from Michigan Street to Taylor Street. 
William Street, from LaSalle to Western. 
(Code 1962, § 25-55; Ord. No. 5566-73, § 1) 
Sec. 20-52. - Parking spaces; designation; method of parking. 
(a)  The City Traffic Director or employees of the City as the Mayor may designate, shall mark off individual parking spaces in the parking zones designated and described in section 20-51 and in such other zones as may hereafter be established. 
(b)  The parking spaces shall be designated by lines or marks painted or durably marked on the curbing or surface of the street about or alongside of each parking meter to designate the parking space for which the meter is to be used. Each vehicle parking alongside of or next to any parking meter shall park within the lines or markings so established. At each space so marked off, no person shall park any vehicle in such a way that the vehicle is not entirely within the limits of the space so designated or across such line or mark. 
(c)  Parking meter spaces shall be approximately eight (8) feet wide and twenty-two (22) feet long for each interior parking space and twenty (20) feet in length for each end parking space at street or alley intersections. Any vehicle parking in any parking space in any parking meter zone shall be parked with the hood of such vehicle alongside of or next to the parking meter. 
(Code 1962, § 25-57) 
Secs. 20-53-20-58. - Reserved.[17] 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note- Section 8 of Ord. No. 8179-91 deleted the provisions of §§ 20-53-20-58, which pertained to parking meters and derived from Code 1962, §§ 25-58-25-60, 25-64, 25-65, 25-69, and Ord. No. 5906-75, § 2. 

Sec. 20-58.1. - Disposition of fees collected for parking and other nonmoving violations. 
    All fees collected for parking and other nonmoving violations under this Chapter 20, the disposition of which is not otherwise specifically provided for by law, shall be deposited in the special fund provided for by state law, and shall be appropriated and disbursed therefrom in the same manner as license fees and funds received from the parking meters. 
(Ord. No. 5508-73, § 1) 
ARTICLE 6. - PROHIBITED ACTIONS 

Sec. 20-59. - Commission of certain acts prohibited. 
    The commission of any of the acts described in this article shall be a violation of this chapter and shall be punishable as an offense as set forth in section 1-23 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6722-79, § 20) 
Sec. 20-60. - Commercial vehicle parking restricted. 
    The parking on public streets of the City of any commercial vehicle, other than pleasure or passenger cars or motorcycles, is prohibited on Sundays and holidays and between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on all days, except when such vehicles are in the act of loading or unloading. 
Sec. 20-61. - Parking limited on certain streets in central commercial area. 
    No person shall stand or park any vehicle upon any public street or alley between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m., within the central commercial area of the City, with the exception of Saturday and Sunday nights, which area shall include: Starting at South Street and William Street; east on South Street to St. Joseph Street; north on St. Joseph Street to Monroe Street; east on Monroe Street to Lincolnway East; north on Lincolnway East to the east-west alley north of 600 block East Monroe Street; east on alley extended to east bank of river; northerly on east river bank to LaSalle Avenue; west on LaSalle Avenue to Lincolnway West; northwest on Lincolnway West to William Street; south on William Street to Wayne Street; west on Wayne Street to Taylor Street; south on Taylor Street to Monroe Street; east on Monroe Street to William Street; south on William Street to South Street. 
(Code 1962, § 25-35) 
Sec. 20-62. - Stop required when traffic obstructed. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indicated to proceed. 
(Code 1962, § 25-39) 
Sec. 20-63. - Stopping or parking near hazardous or congested places. 
    When signs are erected upon approach to hazardous or congested places, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in such designated place. Further, no person shall park a truck or vehicle, as defined in section 20-106, or a recreational vehicle as defined by State Law within fifty (50) feet of any stop sign or in any location that blocks the public right-of-way or the view of any traffic sign. 
(Code 1962, § 25-40; Ord. No. 9042-99, § I) 
Sec. 20-64. - Available street or alley space for traffic; uncontrolled use of alley prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon any street or alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. A driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals or a police officer. 
(Code 1962, § 25-42) 
Sec. 20-65. - Use of alley to private property; approval of Traffic Director. 
    No person shall use or permit to be used an alley as an uncontrolled access-egress to private property. All points of access and/or egress between an alley and private property, excluding access-egress areas for residential parking, must be approved by the Traffic Director. 
Sec. 20-66. - Parking in front of theaters, hotels and between "no parking" signs. 
    No person shall park or cause to be parked or leave standing or cause to be left standing any vehicle on any public street of the City at a point within twenty-five (25) feet from the centerline projected to the curb of the entrance to any theater, moving picture house or hotel in the City, or between "no parking" signs placed on the streets by order of the Chief of Police. 
(Code 1962, § 25-44) 
Sec. 20-67. - Parking prohibited or limited in certain designated places; fine imposed. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any street, alley, municipal parking facility or highway in any area where appropriate signs or markings have been placed indicating that parking is prohibited or that the area is a no-parking zone, nor in any area where signs have been placed indicating that parking is limited to a specified length of time for a period longer than specified upon such signs, nor in any area where signs have been placed indicating that parking is prohibited during certain hours of the day or days or portions of days of the week, during hours or portions of days during the times when parking is prohibited as directed on such signs. 
(b)  Within any period of twenty-four (24) consecutive hours, no vehicle shall be parked at any one (1) or combination of locations in the same block within any time limit zone for a total period of time longer than specified on signs indicating the length of time to which parking is limited. 
(c)  No vehicle shall be parked on public streets within the business district of the City of South Bend, which district shall be bounded by St. Joseph Street to the east, Lasalle Avenue to the north, Lafayette Boulevard to the west, and Monroe Street to the south, nor on designated public highways between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Monday through Friday inclusive. 
(d)  No vehicle shall be parked, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., on City streets which are not within the business district during those periods of time and in those sections of the City so designated by the Director of the Division of Transportation for street sweeping or for leaf pickup. Except that parking will be allowed on said streets at said times as follows: 
(1)  On that side of the street having even-numbered addresses on the even-numbered days of the month; and 
(2)  On that side of the street having odd-numbered addresses on the odd-numbered days of the month. 
(e)  With the exception of signs indicating that parking is prohibited during certain hours on dates of Notre Dame home games or other special events as posted on such signs, nothing in this section is intended to affect the parking of vehicles on Saturdays, Sundays or holidays unless a snow emergency is called according to the provisions of Section 20-103 of Article 7, Chapter 20, of the Municipal Code of the City of South Bend. 
(f)  The Director of the Division of Transportation shall cause to be published within three (3) days of the beginning of each week the schedule for the next week of both street sweeping and leaf pickup. 
(g)  Nothing in this section is intended to affect the already regulated parking on designated snow routes during a snow emergency, or other areas in which parking is regulated by duly authorized signs. 
(h)  The fine for violating any provision in this section shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per violation, except for violations of the prohibition against parking at posted hours on dates of Notre Dame home games or other special events. The fine for parking in violation of special event restrictions shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation, if notice of such fine is posted with the sign. Fines paid pursuant to this section shall be paid at the Ordinance Violations Bureau. 
(Code 1962, § 25-46; Ord. No. 5691-74, § 1; Ord. No. 8089-90, § III; Ord. No. 9131-00, § III; Ord. No. 9276-01, § I; Ord. No. 9490-04, § I; Ord. No. 9626-05, § 1, 9-29-05) 
Sec. 20-68. - Parking in front of business or professional buildings or in City-owned parking facilities restricted. 
(a)  The parking of vehicles on public streets or places of the City in front of any building occupied or used for business or professional purposes and not regulated by this Code or other City ordinances is prohibited for a period exceeding three (3) hours at a time, between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day of the week except Sundays and holidays. 
(b)  The parking facility owned by the City of South Bend at 117 South Lafayette Boulevard is limited to City-owned vehicles and other authorized vehicles of City officials during the hours from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. All such vehicles must display a permit signed by the Board of Public Works. Any vehicle violating this subsection will be immediately towed and impounded at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1962, § 25-43; Ord. No. 5579-73, § 1) 
Sec. 20-69. - Standing for loading only. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or merchandise in any place marked as a loading zone during the hours when the regulations applicable to such loading zone are effective. 
(Code 1962, § 25-47) 
Sec. 20-70. - Bus and taxicab stands; restrictions. 
    The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not stand or park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand respectively; provided, that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Code 1962, § 25-48(a)) 
Sec. 20-71. - Passenger vehicles in bus or taxicab stands. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed; except, that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1962, § 25-48(b)) 
Sec. 20-72. - Method of parking; parallel and single parking; exception for motorcycles. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than parallel to the curb and not more than twelve (12) inches therefrom except where otherwise indicated by this chapter or where the street is marked for a different method of parking. 
(b)  A motorcycle stopped or parked upon a roadway where there is an adjacent curb may be stopped or parked with the rear wheel of the motorcycle to the curb and with the front tire facing the flow of traffic. 
(Code 1962, § 25-49; Ord. No. 8957-98, § I) 
Sec. 20-73. - Right side to the curb. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle with its left side to the curb, except on one-way streets and except as otherwise provided by this chapter or other traffic ordinances. 
Sec. 20-74. - Parking vehicles on streets for sale or repairs; fines. 
(a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying it for sale; or 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(b)  The owner of a vehicle parked for such purposes as established in subsection (a) above, is responsible for the vehicle. The owner shall be ascertained and identified by the officer by means of the license plates and/or vehicle registration. In the event that no license plates and/or vehicle registration are affixed to the vehicle, the vehicle shall be considered abandoned, and the provisions of Article 3 of this chapter shall apply. 
(c)  Fines: The fine for violation of this section shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), and shall be payable through the Ordinance Violations Bureau pursuant to Section 2-213 of this Code. Each day that the vehicle is parked in violation of this section shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1962, § 25-50; Ord. No. 9257-01, § I) 
Sec. 20-75. - Vehicle used for advertising on streets. 
    No person shall operate or park on any street any vehicle for the primary purpose of advertising. 
(Code 1962, § 25-51) 
Sec. 20-76. - Illegal parking; owner's responsibility. 
    No person shall allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or park in any street in this City in violation of this chapter or any ordinances of this City regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(Code 1962, § 25-52) 
Sec. 20-77. - Overtime parking prohibited. 
    No person shall cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked: 
(1)  Beyond the period of legal parking time established for any parking zone established by ordinance; 
(2)  Beyond the period of legal parking time established for any parking meter zone as herein described by depositing in any parking meter any coin for the purpose of parking beyond the maximum legal parking time for the particular parking meter zone, or otherwise; or 
(3)  In any parking space adjacent to any parking meter while the meter is displaying a signal indicating that the time for occupying such space has expired. 
(Code 1962, § 25-61; as amended by Ord. No. 5083-69) 
Sec. 20-78. - Overtime parking; violation. 
    Every period of twelve (12) minutes, or part thereof, in twelve-minute zones, every period of one (1) hour, or part thereof, in one-hour zones, and every period of two (2) hours, or part thereof, in two-hour zones, that any violation of Section 20-77 continues shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable by a separate penalty as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1962, § 25-61; as amended by Ord. No. 5083-69) 
Sec. 20-79. - Injuring or tampering with meters. 
    No person shall injure, deface, tamper willfully with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1962, § 25-62) 
Sec. 20-80. - Use of slugs in meters. 
    No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter installed under the provisions of this chapter any slugs, device or metal substances or other substitute for lawful coins. 
(Code 1962, § 25-63) 
Sec. 20-81. - Limitation on turning vehicles. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall not turn the vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district. He shall not upon any other street so turn a vehicle unless the movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1962, § 25-68) 
Sec. 20-82. - Limitations on backing vehicle. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not back it into an intersection or over a crosswalk. He shall not in any event or at any place back a vehicle unless the movement can be made in safety. 
(Code 1962, § 25-69) 
Sec. 20-83. - Vehicle emerging from alley, building or driveway. 
    The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop the vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or into the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway. Upon entering the roadway he shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Code 1962, § 25-70) 
Sec. 20-84. - Parking on sidewalk, alley or parkway. 
    No person shall park any vehicle on a public sidewalk, in a public alley, or in the parkway between a public sidewalk and a curb. 
Sec. 20-85. - Driving vehicles on sidewalks. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1962, § 25-71) 
Sec. 20-86. - Vehicles on streets being paved or blocked. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle upon any street or alley which is in the process of being paved or resurfaced or upon a street or alley that is closed by barrier or otherwise from public travel. 
(Code 1962, § 25-72) 
Sec. 20-87. - Pedestrians; crossing streets at crosswalks. 
    No pedestrian shall cross any street or highway within the City, except at a marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(Code 1962, § 25-86) 
Sec. 20-88. - Boarding or alighting from vehicles. 
    No person shall board or alight from any vehicle when the vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1962, § 25-88) 
Sec. 20-89. - Unlawful riding; exception. 
    No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers; provided, that this section shall not apply to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1962, § 25-89) 
Sec. 20-90. - Motorcycles; prohibited methods of riding. 
    The operator of a motorcycle, when upon a street, shall not carry any other person upon a handle bar, frame or tank of such vehicle. No person shall so ride upon any such vehicle. 
(Code 1962, § 25-90) 
Sec. 20-91. - Vehicles equipped with spikes and lugs prohibited; exception.[18] 
    No person shall drive or operate or cause to be operated any road engine, traction engine, tractor or any other heavy vehicle having lugs or spikes attached to the tread of the wheels thereof upon or along any asphalt paved street in the City; provided, with the approval of the Traffic Director that such engines or other heavy vehicles may be moved over such streets if run upon material suitable to the City Engineer and/or City Director, carefully placed so as to avoid injury to the surface of the street. 
(Code 1962, § 25-91) 
Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, IC 9-19-18-3. 

Sec. 20-92. - Use of coasters, skates or similar devices restricted. 
    No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway, except while crossing on a crosswalk. 
(Code 1962, § 25-93) 
Sec. 20-93. - Driving through processions.[19] 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when the vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this chapter. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals or Police Officers. 
(Code 1962, § 25-94) 
Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
State Law reference- Power of City to regulate processions, IC 9-21-1-3(3). 

Sec. 20-94. - Permit required for parades or processions. 
(a)  No parade or procession, excepting the forces of the United States Armed Forces, the military forces of this State, the forces of the Police and Fire Department or funeral processions containing less than two hundred (200) persons or less than fifty (50) vehicles, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with a written permit, issued by the Board of Public Works and Safety and such other regulations as are set forth in this Code or other City ordinances which may apply. 
(b)  Application to conduct such parade or procession shall be made in writing to such Board by the person in charge, control or responsible thereof or therefor. Such application shall set forth the route along which such parade or procession is to proceed, the time of starting, the name of the person in control or responsible thereof or therefor, and the purpose of such parade or procession. 
(c)  Upon such application being made, such Board shall investigate or cause to be investigated the person making the application and the truth of the statements made in such application regarding the purpose or object of such parade or procession. 
(d)  If such Board shall find that such parade or procession is not to be held for any unlawful purpose and will not in any manner tend to a breach of the peace, or unnecessarily interfere with the public use of the streets of the City or the peace and quiet of the inhabitants thereof, it shall issue such permit to the person making application therefor. 
(Code 1962, § 25-95) 
Sec. 20-95. - Streets to be unobstructed. 
(a)  No vehicle shall occupy any street so as to interfere with or interrupt the passage of other cars or vehicles. 
(b)  No person shall drive, conduct or load a vehicle in such a manner so as to be likely to cause a blockade, accident, breakdown or injury to man, beast or property. 
(Code 1962, § 25-97) 
Sec. 20-96. - Vehicle load to be deafened. 
    No person shall so load a vehicle with iron or other material that may strike together and produce a great noise, without properly "deafening" it so that it causes no unnecessary noise. 
(Code 1962, § 25-98) 
Sec. 20-97. - Shrubs or plants obstructing view prohibited; trimming. 
(a)  No person shall plant or permit to grow any shrub or plant at or near any street intersection between the property line and the curb which obstructs or tends to obstruct the view of operators of vehicles or of pedestrians. In no case shall any shrub or plant be allowed to grow at any such point to a height exceeding two and one-half (21/2) feet. 
(b)  All shrubs or plants shall be trimmed or cut back by the owners or occupants of abutting property to comply with the requirements of this section, or if such is not possible or practicable, then the shrubs or plants shall be entirely removed. 
(Code 1962, § 25-100) 
Sec. 20-98. - Obedience to School Crossing Guards required-Penalty. 
(a)  No operator of a vehicle or any pedestrian shall disobey the signal or order of a School Crossing Guard with respect to the passage of vehicle or pedestrian in and upon the streets within the City. 
(b)  School Crossing Guards may take the license number of any motorist violating this section and who violates Section 20-131 which prohibits the operator of a motor vehicle to use a hand-held mobile telephone or telecommunications device while driving in a school crossing zone and report, it to the South Bend Police Department. 
(c)  It shall be a violation of this section for the operator of any motor vehicle to fail to stop when ordered to do so by a School Crossing Guard. 
(d)  Any person violating any provisions of this section may be issued a citation which is subject to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00); with all such fines being deposited into the Police Department Training Fund (Fund #220). 
(Ord. No. 4960-67, § 3; Ord. No. 9946-09, § III, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 20-99. - Obedience to official traffic-control devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle, and pedestrians, shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with this chapter, unless otherwise directed by a Police Officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in Section 20-9. 
(Code 1962, § 25-28) 
Sec. 20-100. - Signs required.[20] 
    No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective without signs being directed to give notice thereof. 
(Code 1962, § 25-27) 
Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
State Law reference- Posting of signs giving notice of local traffic regulations, IC 9-21-1-4. 

Sec. 20-100.1. - Parking by fire hydrants prohibited. 
(a)  Any motor vehicle found parallel parked within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant or in a designated fire hydrant no parking zone shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00). Additionally, any motor vehicle found in violation of this section may be towed at the owner's expense. 
(b)  Appropriate markings giving notice of this parking prohibition shall be properly posted by the City. 
(Ord. No. 8358-93, § 1; Ord. No. 8376-93, § 1) 
ARTICLE 7. - SNOW REMOVAL[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7132-82, § 3, adopted Nov. 22, 1982, repealed former Art. 7, which contained §§ 20-101-20-105 and was derived from Ord. No. 6488-78, § 1. Section 3 of Ord. No. 7132-82 enacted a new Art. 7, pertaining to similar subject matter, and designated as §§ 20-101-20-106. Inasmuch as the Code already contained a § 20-106, the last section of the new Art. 7 was redesignated by the editor as § 20-105.1. 

Sec. 20-101. - Definitions. 
(a)  Snow removal condition means a formal declaration by the appropriate person, that, in his or her opinion, the actual or expected precipitation will create hazardous or dangerous street or sidewalk conditions. Such declaration shall take one (1) of the following forms: 
(1)  Snow route clearance condition. 
(2)  Street clearance condition. 
(3)  Winter weather emergency condition. 
(b)  Snow route clearance condition means a snow removal condition which addresses all designated snow routes (main routes). 
(c)  Street clearance condition means a snow-removal condition which addresses all City streets. 
(d)  Winter weather emergency condition means a formal declaration by the mayor or, in [the] mayor's absence, the mayor's designee, that the occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury or loss of life or property resulting from a snow storm requires emergency action. 
(e)  Snow means any precipitation depositing any accumulation on the streets, including snow, sleet, hail, ice and freezing rain. 
(f)  Snow routes means all streets in the city so designated and marked. 
(g)  Vehicles means all self-propelled motorized licensed vehicles using city streets and highways, excluding public transportation conveyances. 
(Ord. No. 7132-82, § 3; Ord. No. 7404-84, § 1; Ord. No. 10345-15, § I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 20-102. - Clearing of sidewalks. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant of any premises abutting or adjoining any city street to remove, or cause to be removed, all snow and ice from the public sidewalk within twenty-four (24) hours after such snow and ice has fallen or accumulated thereon. If any owner or occupant fails to comply with this subsection, the city may remove the snow and ice pursuant to section 18-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 7132-82, § 3; Ord. No. 7404-84, § 1) 
Sec. 20-103. - Snow routes; designation and posting. 
(a)  The board of public works shall designate as snow routes streets which are heavily traveled and are necessary thoroughfares for the movement of vehicular traffic through the city. 
(b)  Streets designated as snow routes shall be posted with suitable signs. 
(Ord. No. 7132-82, § 3; Ord. No. 7404-84, § 1) 
Sec. 20-104. - Snow removal conditions. 
(a)  If the mayor or the Director of Public Works for the City of South Bend, or the mayor's designee, determines that the actual or expected accumulation of snow, sleet, hail, ice and/or freezing rain is creating or will create hazardous or dangerous street and sidewalk conditions of sufficient severity to require specialized snow removal procedures, the mayor or the Director of Public Works, or the mayor's designee, shall have the authority to declare that one (1) of the following snow removal conditions exists: 
(1)  Snow route clearance conditions. 
(2)  Street clearance conditions. 
(b)  The mayor alone, or in the mayor's absence, the mayor's designee shall have the authority to declare that a winter weather emergency condition exists as defined [in] Section 20-101(d) of this article. 
(c)  All snow removal conditions shall be declared by the appropriate person, by issuing a press release to local radio, television, newspaper and other news services. Such declaration shall be made which contains the following information: Date, time and reason for declaration, the actual or anticipated weather conditions at time of declaration. Such declaration shall be signed by the mayor or the Director of Public Works, or the mayor's designee, and a copy filed, as soon as possible, with the office of the City Clerk, where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(d)  Once declared, the snow removal condition shall continue until the mayor or the Director of Public Works, or the mayor's designee, declares it to be ended in the same manner as provided for its declaration in subsection (b). Such declaration shall be signed by the mayor or, the Director of Public Works, or the mayor's designee, and a copy filed, as soon as possible with the office of the City Clerk, where it shall be available for public inspection. Only the mayor or the mayor's designee may declare a winter weather emergency condition to be ended. 
(e)  Snow removal conditions may be declared for the entire City or any part thereof, as the mayor or the Director of Public works, or the mayor's designee, deems necessary for effective snow removal. 
(Ord. No. 7132-82, § 3; Ord. No. 7404-84, § 1; Ord. No. 10345-15, § II, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 20-105. - Traffic regulations during snow removal conditions. 
(a)  Snow route clearance conditions . When snow route clearance conditions are declared to exist, the following traffic regulations shall be in effect: 
(1)  No vehicle shall be parked on a street designated as a snow route. 
(2)  Any vehicle parked, stalled, incapable of moving under its own power or left unattended on any street designated as a snow route shall be issued a citation and/or towed and/or impounded. 
(3)  Provided, however, that no such vehicle shall be issued a citation and/or towed and/or impounded if the street upon which it is parked has been plowed by the City in such a manner that all traffic and parking lanes are open and clear of snow. 
(4)  The owner of any vehicle in violation of this article shall be responsible for all citation fines, towing and storage fees. Citations under this article shall be issued as provided in Section 20-17 of this chapter. 
(b)  Street snow clearance conditions . When street snow clearance conditions are declared to exist, the following traffic regulations shall be in effect: 
(1)  Parking shall be banned from 8:00 a.m. until 8:00 a.m. the following morning on all streets not designated as snow routes in accord with one (1) of the following schedules: 
a.  Even-numbered days-Parking solely on even address street sides (parking solely on south or east sides of streets) even if street is designated or posted as "no parking". 
b.  Odd-numbered days-Parking solely on odd address street sides (parking solely on north or west sides of streets) even if street is designated or posted as "no parking". 
(3)  Any vehicle parked, stalled, incapable of moving under its own power or left unattended upon any street in violation of this section shall be issued a citation and/or towed and/or impounded upon discovery. 
(4)  Provided, however, that no such vehicle shall be issued a citation and/or towed and/or impounded if the street upon which it is parked has been plowed by the City in such a manner that all traffic and parking lanes are open and clear of snow. 
(5)  The owner of any vehicle in violation of this article shall be responsible for all citation fines, towing and storage fees. Citations under this article shall be issued as provided in Section 20-17 of this chapter. 
(c)  Winter weather emergency conditions . When winter weather emergency conditions as defined [in] Section 20-101(d) of this article are declared to exist, the following regulations shall be in effect: 
(1)  The mayor alone or the mayor's designee, shall have the following powers: 
a.  To limit traffic within the City. 
b.  To establish such parking regulations as he or she deems necessary. 
c.  To designate both City-owned vehicles and privately owned vehicles as "temporary service vehicles." 
d.  To exercise all authority granted pursuant to IC 10-14-3-1 et seq., the Emergency Management and Disaster Law, regulating civil defense disaster law if he or she deems weather conditions to be severe enough to implement such emergency powers. 
(Ord. No. 7132-82, § 3; Ord. No. 7404-84, § 1; Ord. No. 10345-15, § III, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 20-105.1. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found to be in violation of Section 20-105 of this article shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(b)  Enforcement of Section 20-105 shall be by the Police Department, Code Enforcement Department, and other entities consistent with policies and procedures set forth in Section 20-17; with all fines being paid through the Ordinance Violations Bureau. 
(Ord. No. 7132-82, § 3; Ord. No. 7404-84, § 1; Ord. No. 10345-15, § IV, 1-26-15) 
ARTICLE 8. - TRUCK ROUTES[22] 

Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 7685-86, § 1, adopted Sept. 22, 1986, deleted Art. 8, §§ 20-106-20-109.7, in its entirety and enacted a new Art. 8, §§ 20-106-20-109.7. Former Art. 8 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1962, § 25-79, 25-80; Ord. No. 5047-68, § 1; and Ord. No. 6648-79, § 1. 
Cross reference- Commercial vehicle parking limited, § 20-60. 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate trucks, IC 9-20-1-3. 

Sec. 20-106. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall mean: 
    Truck, as the term is used in this section, is a vehicle having three (3) axles or a vehicle over ten thousand [pounds] (10,000) gross vehicle weight, and includes semi-trailer trucks and either the tractor pulling the same, or the trailer itself. Truck includes every self-propelled commercial vehicle designed, used or maintained for the commercial transport of goods or property. [23] 
    City block, as the term is used in this section, is that portion of a public street bounded by the highest and lowest numbers within any sequence of 100s, such as 200 to 299, 300 to 399, etc. 
    This article also applies to any vehicles manufactured, assembled or modified on a commercial or military basis and transported or operated on/in the streets of the City of South Bend. Such vehicles must be so operated on truck routes in accordance with this ordinance. This shall include any and all vehicle manufactured, assembled, modified, transported or operated singularly or in quantity by any business operating in or through the City of South Bend. 
(Ord. No. 7685-86, § 1; Ord. No. 7923-88, § 1)

(b)  All trucks or vehicles as defined in Section 20-106 shall follow state or national highways and City truck routes as shown on "Schedule A-1". They shall not travel upon any other public streets of the City, except as provided in Section 20-108(c). 
(Ord. No. 7685-86, § 1; Ord. No. 7702-86, § 1; Ord. No. 7923-88, § 2)

Sec. 20-108. - Restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall drive any truck or vehicle as defined in section 20-106 upon any public streets not designated as a truck route in "Schedule A-1" of the City at any time; provided that such trucks or vehicles may be permitted upon such other public streets of the City, upon the direction of a City or State police officer, to follow a marked and established City detour, to obtain necessary emergency mechanical repairs, or if for safety reasons upon the prior approval of the City Engineer and the Police Department. 
(b)  All trucks and vehicles as defined in section 20-106 shall proceed by the shortest combination of State and Federal highways and City truck routes shown upon "Schedule A-1," and shall be prohibited from driving upon any other City streets unless said vehicle is in the process of delivering or picking up goods as further addressed in subsection (c) herein or is itself in the process of being delivered. A written bill of lading or similar document must be produced by the driver if stopped while driving on a City street which is not designated as a City truck route as shown in "Schedule A-1," or detour route to verify such pickup or delivery. 
(c)  All trucks as defined in section 20-106, when finished delivering or picking up goods within the City, shall return to the nearest truck route by the most direct route, unless the truck has a subsequent delivery or pick-up scheduled within the immediate vicinity for that day. In such cases the truck may proceed to a subsequent pick-up or subsequent delivery location(s) only if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The driver has in his or her possession a written bill of lading or similar document for the next subsequent delivery or will have a pick-up order upon reaching said subsequent pick-up location(s); 
(2)  The driver has in his or her possession a written manifest or similar document which shows in clear and plain English all of the scheduled delivery or pick-up location(s) for that day; and 
(3)  The distance from the first delivery or pick-up location off the truck route to the next subsequent delivery(s) or pick-up location(s) is not greater than a total of nine (9) city blocks from the first delivery or pick-up location. 
So long as the conditions of this section are met, it is the intent of this section to permit as many subsequent deliveries or pick-ups from the initial location which was off of the designated truck route so long as such subsequent deliveries or pick-ups are within the maximum nine (9) city block distance from the initial delivery or pick-up location. It is the further intent of this section to permit subsequent deliveries or pick-ups by the truck if such subsequent deliveries or pick-ups are on the most direct route back to the designated truck route. 
(d)  Any truck driver who is stopped by a Police Officer on a street which is not designated as a truck route, and who does not have a written bill of lading and a written manifest or similar documents as required by sub-paragraph (c) herein, shall be in violation of this section and shall be issued a citation. 
(e)  The Board of Public Works may designate, from time to time, by proper resolution, specific streets or blocks thereof, where trucks are expressly prohibited due to safety reasons or engineering standards. The City shall post signs prohibiting trucks in such designated locations. Any truck driving in such prohibited areas shall be in violation of this section and shall be issued a citation. 
(f)  No person shall stop, stand or park a truck as defined in section 20-106 on any street, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of freight, except in cases of emergency when such truck is broken down and unable to move, and except also in the event a moving van is loading or unloading furniture and household goods, or the furniture and equipment and goods, wares and merchandise of a business, in either of which events the operator of such truck will have a reasonable time in which to complete his loading or unloading and move his truck. 
(Ord. No. 7685-86, § 1; Ord. No. 7923-88, § 3) 
Sec. 20-109. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article do not apply to vehicles: 
(1)  Licensed to operate upon trucks; 
(2)  Licensed to carry passengers for hire; 
(3)  Municipal government vehicles operating on official business; or 
(4)  Public utility vehicles operating on official business. 
(Ord. No. 7685-86, § 1; Ord. No. 7923-88, § IV) 
Sec. 20-109.5. - Signs. 
    The Bureau of Traffic and Lighting is hereby authorized to cause all streets and portions thereof established and designed by this article as truck routes to be clearly marked or signposted at their intersections with other truck routes or boundary lines of the City, with appropriate signs displaying in letters not less than four (4) inches in height the words "Truck Route." 
(Ord. No. 7685-86, § 1) 
Sec. 20-109.7. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found in violation of any provision of this article shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense, no less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second offense, and not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the third or subsequent offense, with a citation being issued for each violation. 
(b)  In addition to the citation procedure, a fine up to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) may be imposed upon conviction. 
(Ord. No. 7685-86, § 1) 
ARTICLE 9. - MOBILITY HANDICAPPED PARKING[24] 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Editor's note- Section IV of Ord. No. 8089-90 amended Art. 9 in its entirety by amending § 20-110, repealing § 20-111, renumbering §§ 20-112 and 20-113 as §§ 20-111 and 20-112, and amending those 2 sections. Former § 20-111 was derived from Ord. No. 6388-78, § 3, and Ord. No. 7435-85, § 1. 

Sec. 20-110. - Qualified persons. 
(a)  Disabled Veteran Registration Plates. A person who has been issued disabled veteran registration plate(s) by this or any other state and who displays said plate(s) shall be entitled to all of the parking privileges authorized by this article. 
(b)  Special Registration Plate. A person who has been issued special registration plate(s) bearing the official international wheelchair symbol or a reasonable facsimile thereof by this or any other state and who displays said plate(s) shall be entitled to all of the parking privileges authorized by this article. 
(c)  State of Indiana Handicapped Parking Permit. A person or authorized commercial vehicle specifically designed to transport mobility handicapped persons for a fee, who have been issued a handicapped parking permit by the State, bearing a permit number, signature of the authorizing State official(s), and the official international wheelchair symbol or a reasonable facsimile thereof shall be entitled to all of the parking privileges authorized by this article. 
(Ord. No. 6388-78, § 3; Ord. No. 7435-85, § 1; Ord. No. 8089-90, § IV) 
Sec. 20-111. - Designation of handicapped parking spaces. 
(a)  Any person on behalf of any mobility handicapped person or authorized group organization representing the handicapped may request the Board of Public Works to designate a space or spaces for handicapped parking. 
(b)  The Board shall refer such request(s) to the Bureau of Traffic and Lighting for review and recommendation. 
(c)  Upon the receipt of the Bureau of Traffic and Lighting review and recommendation, the Board shall either accept, modify or deny said recommendation. 
(d)  Upon the Board's designation of a space for handicapped parking, a sign shall be installed bearing the words: 
HANDICAPPED PARKING ONLY DISABLED LICENSE OR PERMIT REQUIRED 
or similar language consistent with the State manual and specifications for uniform system of traffic-control devices, and the official international wheelchair symbol or a reasonable facsimile thereof. All angle parking spaces so designated shall be at least thirteen (13) feet wide. 
(Ord. No. 6388-78, § 3; Ord. No. 6761-80, § 1; Ord. No. 8040-89, § 1; Ord. No. 8089-90, § IV) 
Sec. 20-112. - Penalties. 
    Any motor vehicle found parking in areas designated for the exclusive use of mobility disabled persons which does not bear a disabled veteran registration plate, a special registration plate, or display a disabled parking permit issued by any State or municipality, shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00). Additionally, any motor vehicle found in violation of this section for longer than one (1) hour shall be towed at the owner's expense. Continuing violations under this section shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable by a separate penalty for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 6388-78, § 3; Ord. No. 6761-80, § 2; Ord. No. 7992-89, § 6; Ord. No. 8040-89, § 2; Ord. No. 8089-90, § IV; Ord. No. 10246-13, § I, 8-12-13) 
Sec. 20-113. - Definitions. 
(a)  Physically disabled person as used in this section means any individual with a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of the major life activities of such individual as defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(b)  Full-time employee as used in this section means an individual who, pursuant to their employment relationship, works not less than thirty-five (35) hours per week. 
(c)  Central business district as used in this section shall have the same meaning as that definition employed at subsection 2-76.1(a)(2) of the South Bend Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 8518-94, § 1) 
Sec. 20-113.1. - Authority. 
(a)  The Board of Public Works for the City of South Bend is hereby authorized and empowered to grant to physically disabled persons the exclusive use of parking space adjacent to or directly across the street from their place of employment, subject to such rules and regulations the Board may prescribe in areas where such parking is otherwise permitted, in the manner provided herein. 
(b)  Any person eligible by virtue of a physical or mental disability for special privileges under this section shall present to the Board a written application, on a form furnished by the Board, for a permit entitling that person to the exclusive use for a period of one calendar year from the date of issue of one parking space adjacent to or directly across the street from the applicant's place of employment. Such application shall include a certificate by a qualified physician verifying that the applicant is a physically disabled person. Such an application for parking at a place of employment shall include evidence of approval by the employer as well as the information regarding the applicant's daily work schedule. The application must also provide verification from the individual's supervisor at their place of employment attesting to the fact that the employer has exhausted all efforts at providing parking for the individual. 
(c)  Upon receipt of such written application, the Board shall, within a reasonable time grant or deny the permit applied for, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  No applicant shall be granted a permit for more than one reserved space adjacent to or directly across the street from the applicant's place of employment. 
(2)  No applicant shall be granted a permit if it can be demonstrated that the applicant has failed to exhaust other parking opportunities which are comparable in distance to the applicant's place of employment. 
(3)  No applicant shall be granted a permit unless the applicant's employer provides the board with information that the applicant's employer is unable to provide the applicant with any other parking opportunities comparable to that which the City is able to provide in terms of distance from the applicant's place of employment. The burden is on the applicant and the applicant's employer to demonstrate to the Board that the applicant's employer is unable to provide the applicant with a parking area that adequately meets the needs of the applicant. 
(4)  No applicant shall be granted a permit without first demonstrating to the Board that the individual is a full-time employee. 
(5)  Each permit granted pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be assigned an identification number. 
(d)  Upon the grant of such permit, the Board shall: 
(1)  Issue to the applicant a reserved space permit with an identification number. 
(2)  Install a sign restricting the use of the parking area to the permit holder only, which sign shall show thereon the holder's permit number. 
(3)  Order that the signage for the reserved space parking area contain the hours for which the parking area shall be designated as a reserved space parking area. 
(e)  The number of reserved space parking areas shall be limited to a total of two (2) spaces on each side of any one city block. 
(Ord. No. 8518-94, § 1) 
Sec. 20-113.2. - Issuance of permit. 
    From and after the granting of such permit, the permit holder shall: 
(1)  Conspicuously display the reserved space permit in the windshield of any vehicle used by the permit holder and parked in the reserved space. 
(2)  Promptly notify the Board if there is any change in the permit holder's employment situation so as to allow the Board the opportunity to determine whether or not the permit holder remains entitled to the reserved space. 
(3)  Notify the Board of any change in the permit holder's status as a physically disabled person within five (5) days of such a change in status. 
    Any failure by a permit holder to comply with the above requirements shall be grounds for the Board to revoke this reserved space permit. 
(Ord. No. 8518-94, § 1) 
Sec. 20-113.3. - Validity and renewal of permit. 
(a)  A reserved space permit shall be valid for one (1) year after its issuance and shall be subject to renewal each year. A reserved space permit holder must submit to the Board a renewal form issued by the Board in order to renew the reserved space permit. Further, the Board may, at any time, request that the reserve space permit holder present evidence to the Board that the permit holder is engaged in full-time employment and is still employed at the same location that appears on the permit holder's application. 
(b)  The Board shall assess a monthly fee to be assessed for the use of a reserved space parking permit. This monthly fee shall be commensurate to the administrative cost of enforcing this section. 
(c)  The terms and provisions of this Section shall not apply outside of the Central Business District of the City of South Bend. 
(d)  Nothing in this Section shall be construed to require the City to create reserved space parking areas in on-street locations where parking is otherwise prohibited or limited to a duration of time less than one (1) hour. 
(Ord. No. 8518-94, § 1) 
Sec. 20-113.4. - Penalties. 
    The parking of a vehicle by any person in a space reserved hereunder during the hours such space is reserved without a visible permit showing such parking to be authorized shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00). Continuing violations under this section shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable by a separate penalty for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 8518-94, § 1; Ord. No. 10246-13, § II, 8-12-13) 
ARTICLE 10. - RESIDENTIAL PARKING ZONES[25] 

Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
Cross reference- Commercial vehicle parking restricted, § 20-60. 

Sec. 20-114. - Application process; parking study authorized. 
(a)  The lawful residents of a residential area within the City may request the Board of Public Works to restrict parking on the public streets within the residential area to residents only by the establishment of a residential parking zone. The request shall be in the form of a petition signed by two-thirds of the lawful residents of the residential area, setting forth the boundaries of the residential area to be included in the residential parking zone and an explanation of the need for the parking restriction. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the petition, the Board of Public Works shall authorize a parking study of the residential area to be conducted by the Bureau of Traffic and Lighting. In conducting the study, the Bureau of Traffic and Lighting shall consider the following factors in determining whether a parking restriction for the residential area is warranted: 
(1)  The proximity of the residential area to industrial, commercial, educational or public service facilities and the off-street parking spaces available for persons utilizing such facilities; 
(2)  The number of vehicles operated by persons whose destination is a facility described in subsection (1) above which are parked on the public streets within the residential area under consideration; 
(3)  The total number of parking spaces available on the public streets within the residential area under consideration; 
(4)  Any days of the week or times of day in which parking on the public streets within the residential area under consideration particularly may be congested. 
(c)  The Bureau of Traffic and Lighting shall not recommend that a parking restriction is warranted unless the average number of vehicles operated by persons whose destination is a facility described in subsection (b)(1) above is in excess of twenty-five (25) percent of the total number of parking spaces available on the public streets within the residential area, and the total number of parking spaces on the public streets occupied by motor vehicles exceeds seventy-five (75) percent of the total number of parking spaces on the public streets in the residential area under consideration. The recommendation may be limited to a restriction on parking only for specific days of the week or specific times of day, and may recommend that the parking restriction be designated only for certain public streets within the residential area under consideration. 
(Ord. No. 6663-79, § 1) 
Sec. 20-115. - Designation. 
(a)  Upon recommendation of the Bureau of Traffic and Lighting, the Board of Public Works may designate the residential area under consideration as a residential parking zone. The designation shall set forth the boundaries of the residential area and the parking restrictions shall be applicable only to the public streets of the residential area so designated. The designation shall set forth any limitations as to the days of the week or times of the day in which such restriction shall be in force. A copy of the designation shall be kept on file with the clerk of the Board of Public Works. 
(b)  Parking on the public streets within the residential area designated as a residential parking zone shall be restricted to vehicles displaying a residential parking decal issued by the Board of Public Works. Any lawful resident of the residential area so designated shall be entitled to a residential parking decal; however, there shall be a limit of three (3) decals issued per family, as defined in section 21-11 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6663-79, § 2) 
Sec. 20-116. - Penalty. 
    When signs are erected giving notice, any motor vehicle parked in a residential parking zone in violation of the restrictions for parking in the zone and which does not display a residential parking decal may be ticketed and/or towed at the owner's expense in accordance with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6663-79, § 3) 
ARTICLE 11. - PARKING OF TRUCKS HAVING MORE THAN ELEVEN THOUSAND POUNDS' GROSS VEHICLE WEIGHT 

Sec. 20-117. - Definition. 
    When used in this article: 
    Truck shall be defined as a motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property whose declared gross vehicle weight when empty exceeds eleven thousand (11,000) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 6838-80, § 1) 
Sec. 20-118. - Parking restricted. 
(a)  No person shall park a truck as heretofore defined on any street next to an area zoned "A" or "A-1" Residence Districts, "A-2" or "A-3" Planned Residential Districts, or "B" or "B-1" Residence Districts, except for the purpose of loading, unloading, servicing, or being then involved in the repair or construction of a residence. Such trucks shall be allowed to park on such residential streets when being used in connection with servicing a public utility. 
(b)  All such trucks may be parked in a carport, private garage, or driveway unless otherwise restricted by the zoning code. 
(c)  All trucks, regardless of declared gross vehicle weight, which are used for picking up trash on a commercial basis are strictly prohibited from parking on any residential street except for the purpose of loading. 
(d)  No person shall park any vehicle in an SF1 Single Family and Two Family District, SF2 Single Family and Two Family District or MF1 Urban Corridor Multifamily District or MF2 High Density Multifamily District in violation of Section 21-02.01, 21-02.02 or 21-02.03 or 21-02.04 of the South Bend Municipal Code. 
(e)  No person shall park any vehicle on an unimproved vacant lot in an "A" Residential District, "A-1" Residential District, "B" Residential District, "C" Commercial District, or "D" Light Industrial District in violation of Section 21-04.01 of the South Bend Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 6838-80, § 1; Ord. No. 9257-01, § II) 
Sec. 20-119. - Penalties. 
    Any owner of any truck or other vehicle which is found illegally parked on any residential street or lot, and the owners and occupants of any residential property who allow such parking in violation of Section 20-118 shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for all subsequent offenses. Fines issued under this section shall be payable through the Ordinance Violations Bureau pursuant to Section 2-213 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6838-80, § 1; Ord. No. 9257-01, § III) 
ARTICLE 12. - MOTOR VEHICLE NOISE CONTROL[26] 

Footnotes: 
--- (26) --- 
Cross reference- Loud and raucous noise, § 13-57. 

Sec. 20-120. - Legislative findings. 
(a)  The South Bend Common Council hereby finds that there is a need to develop better noise control regulations in light of the serious hazards which excessive noise can cause to public health, welfare, safety, and the quality of life. 
(b)  The Council therefore declares that the following motor vehicle noise control regulations shall apply to all motor vehicles operating in the City of South Bend, Indiana. 
(Ord. No. 6938-81, § 1) 
Sec. 20-121. - Definitions. 
(1)  A-weighted sound level. The sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so read is designated db(A) or dBA. 
(2)  Decibel (db). A unit for measuring the volume of a sound, equal to twenty (20) times the logarithm to the base ten (10) of the ratio of the pressure of the sound measured to the reference pressure, which is twenty (20) miscopascals (twenty (20) micronewtons per square meter). 
(3)  Light-motor vehicles. Any automobile, van, motorcycle, motor-driven cycle, motorscooter, dune buggy, snowmobile, all terrain vehicles, go-carts, minibikes, trail bikes, and trucks with gross vehicular weights of less than eight thousand (8,000) pounds. 
(4)  Modified and defective exhaust systems. An exhaust system in which the original noise abatement devices have been physically altered causing them to be less effective in reducing noise as their original devices, or devices [which] have been added to the original noise abatement devices such that noise levels are increased. 
(5)  Noise level. The A-weighted sound level produced by motor vehicles. 
(6)  Person. Any individual, association, partnership or corporation which includes any officer, employee, department, agency or instrumentality. 
(7)  Sound level meter. An instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time averager, output meter, and weighting networks used to measure sound pressure levels. Such instrument shall be used for measurement of the intensity of sound and calibrated in decibels as standardized by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). Readings shall be made on a db(A) scale. 
(8)  Traffic noise. Sound made by a motor vehicle operated either on the public right-of-way or private property. 
    All definitions and terminology used in this Code not defined above, shall be defined in conformance with an applicable publication of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI), or its successor body. 
(Ord. No. 6938-81, § 1) 
Sec. 20-122. - Noise limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause noise levels from the operation or use of light- motor vehicles in excess of eighty (80) dB(A) in any area within the corporate limits of the City of South Bend, Indiana, at any time. Such noise level limit shall be measured on a distance of not less than fifteen (15) feet from the noise source. 
(Ord. No. 6938-81, § 1) 
Sec. 20-123. - Excessive noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to operate or use a light-motor vehicle such as to cause excessive noise levels as a result of a defective or modified exhaust system, or as a result of unnecessary rapid acceleration, deceleration, revving or tire squealing, or as the result of the operation of radio devices such as but not limited to radios, phonographs, horns and tape players on or from such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 6938-81, § 1) 
Sec. 20-124. - Exemptions. 
    The following are exempted from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Sound emitted from sirens of authorized emergency vehicles; 
(2)  Burglar alarms on light-motor vehicles of the electronic signaling type which transmit an audible signal to a receiver which can be carried by the owner or operator of the vehicle; and 
(3)  Celebrations in connection with duly authorized parades. 
(Ord. No. 6938-81, § 1) 
Sec. 20-125. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person shall be found guilty of violation of this article for the emission of the excessive noise from or on any motor vehicle source in excess of the limitations established herein. Such violations shall be proven by evidence of a noise level as tested by a sound level meter which meets or exceeds the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) specifications for Type II equipment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this article. Whenever any Police Officer believes that this article has been violated he shall take down the name, address, operator's license number and registration number of the vehicle if readily available, and shall issue to the alleged violator in writing a citation for the violation. 
(c)  Upon conviction of violation of this article, the violator shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense; not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second offense; and not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for all offenses thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 6938-81, § 1) 
Sec. 20-126. - Street signs. 
    The City of South Bend may post street signs bearing the following symbol: 
on all main arterial streets leading into the City, and at other locations deemed necessary by the Board of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 6938-81, § 1) 
Secs. 20-127-20-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 13. - REGULATIONS ON THE USE OF HAND-HELD MOBILE TELEPHONES, MOBILE COMMUNICATION DEVICES AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEVICES IN SCHOOL ZONES 

Sec. 20-130. - Definitions. 
    In this section: 
(1)  Engaging in a call means talking into, dialing or listening on a hand-held mobile telephone, but does not include holding a mobile telephone to activate or deactivate the telephone. 
(2)  Hand-held mobile telephone means a mobile telephone with which a user engages in a call using at least one hand (or prosthetic device or aid in the case of a physically disabled person). 
(3)  Hands-free mobile telephone means a mobile telephone that has an internal feature or function or that is equipped with an attachment or addition, whether or not permanently part of the mobile telephone, by which a user engages in a call without the use of either hand (or prosthetic device or aid in the case of a physically disabled person) whether or not the use of either hand (or prosthetic device) is necessary to activate or deactivate the mobile telephone. 
(4)  Mobile communication device means a text-messaging device or other electronic, two-way communication device that is designed to receive and transmit voice communication, text communication, or both. The term includes a mobile telephone and a personal digital assistant (PDA). 
(5)  Mobile telephone means a device used by subscribers and other users of wireless telephone service to access such service. 
(6)  School crossing zone means a part of a roadway distinctly indicated for crossing by children on the way to or from school by lines or other markings on the surface of the roadway or by signs. 1 
(7)  Text message means a two-way communication (whether real-time or asynchronous) in which data (composed in whole or in part of text, numbers, images or symbols) is sent, entered or received by a method other than by voice and transmitted through either a short message service (SMS) or a computer network. The term does not include a communication transmitted through a global positioning or navigation system. 
(8)  Telecommunications device means an electronic or digital telecommunications device or digital telecommunications device as addressed in Indiana Code §9-24-11-0.5, and includes hand-held mobile telephones and mobile communication devices. 
(9)  Wireless telephone service means two-way, real time voice telecommunications service that is interconnected to a public switched telephone network and is commonly referred to as cellular service or personal communication service. 
(Ord. No. 9946-09, § I, 7-27-09) 
1 Indiana Code 9-13-2-161.5 addresses school crossing zones. 
Sec. 20-131. - Drivers prohibited to use hand-held mobile telephones, mobile communication devices and telecommunication devices while driving in school crossing zone. 
(a)  A person violates this article if the person uses a hand-held mobile telephone to engage in a call or uses a mobile communication device or other telecommunication device to send, read, or write a text message, while operating a moving motor vehicle in a school crossing zone: 
(1)  On an official school day; 
(2)  During the hours when the school crossing zone is in effect; 
(3)  When signs are conspicuously posted to indicate the beginning and end of the school zone; or 
(4)  When signs stating "NO TEXT-MESSAGING OR HAND-HELD CELL PHONE USE IN SCHOOL ZONE" or similar language are conspicuously posted at each entrance to the school zone. 
(b)  An operator of a motor vehicle who holds a mobile telephone or telecommunications device to or in the immediate proximity of his or her ear while the vehicle is in motion is presumed to be engaging in a call under this article. Immediate proximity is any distance that permits the user of a mobile telephone or telecommunication device to hear telecommunications transmitted over the telephone or device and does not require physical contact with the user's ear. 
(Ord. No. 9946-09, § I, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 20-132. - Limited exceptions. 
    If the person operating a moving motor vehicle in a school crossing zone was: 
(1)  Operating an authorized emergency vehicle and using a hand-held mobile telephone, mobile communication device or other telecommunications devise in the course and scope of the person's official duties; 
(2)  Using the mobile telephone or mobile communication device to: 
a.  Report illegal activity to a law enforcement agency; 
b.  Communicate with an emergency response operator, a fire department, a law enforcement agency, a hospital, a physician's office, or a health clinic regarding a medical or other emergency situation; or 
c.  Is using a hands-free mobile telephone in a hands-free manner shall be considered exempt from the provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 9946-09, § I, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 20-133. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any provisions of this article shall be issued a citation and be subject to the following fines: 
(1)  Seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for the first violation; 
(2)  One hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for the second violation; 
(3)  Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for all subsequent violations. 
However, if a person violating any provisions of this article has an accident in a school crossing zone, the citation shall automatically result in a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(b)  Any person issued a citation for violating any provision of this article shall make payment through the Ordinance Violations Bureau. Failure to make payment within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the citation shall result in the assessment of a late fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(c)  Each violation of the article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 9946-09, § I, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 20-134. - Deposit of fine monies into Police Department Training Fund. 
(a)  All monies collected and retained by the City for violation of this article shall be deposited into the Police Department Training Fund (Fund #220). Such monies shall be used solely for the purposes designated for such fund. Any and all interest earned on the monies deposited in Fund #220 shall not revert to the General Fund. 
(b)  The Department of Administration and Finance shall send monthly written reports to the Office of the City Clerk detailing the amount of money collected and the amount of interest earned, with such reporting being filed no later than the last business day of each month. 
(Ord. No. 9946-09, § I, 7-27-09) 
Secs. 20-135-20-139. - Reserved.
